assesses an individual\u2019s evaluation of their own aging, and has been widely used in the field of subjective aging literature. The present study examined whether the ATOA scale measures the same construct across middle-aged (40\u201360), young-old (61\u201374), and old-old adults (ages 75 or older) and also evaluated the construct validity of the ATOA construct in relation to measures of subjective well-being. Data drawn from the 2008 wave of the German Aging Survey (DEAS; n = 6091) were used. ATOA was assessed by the ATOA subscale of the Philadelphia Geriatric Center Morale Scale (PGCMS), and subjective well-being was assessed with the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) and the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS). Confirmatory factor analysis revealed that the model fit of the one-factor model consisting of four items fits the data well. Multi-group invariance analyses provide evidence for configural and metric invariance of the ATOA scale across the age groups, but not for scalar invariance. Additional analysis assessing construct validity indicated that the ATOA items exhibited convergent validity. The findings support the utility of the 4-item scale when examining age group differences of ATOA across a wide age range and that ATOA is distinct from measures of subjective well-being.", 'container-title':"Journal of Adult Development", DOI:"10/gdjsb3", journalAbbreviation:"Journal of Adult Development", language:"en", source:"ResearchGate", title:"Attitude Toward Own Aging: Age Invariance and Construct Validity Across Middle-Aged, Young-Old, and Old-Old Adults", 'title-short':"Attitude Toward Own Aging", volume:"25", author:[{family:"Jung", given:"Seojung"}, {family:"Siedlecki", given:"Karen"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2018", 6, 1]]}}}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0]], []

(3)(+0000013): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"pfT4aYdw", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2018)", plainCitation:"(2018)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9652, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/TQDNXB36"], itemData:{id:9652, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Objectives: The original 24-item Attitudes to Ageing Questionnaire (AAQ) is well-established as a measure of attitudes to aging, comprising domains of Psychosocial Loss (PL), Physical Change (PC), and Psychological Growth (PG). This paper presents a new 12-item short form Attitudes to Ageing Questionnaire (AAQ-SF). Methods: The original field trial data used to develop the AAQ-24 were used to compare 6-,9- and 12-item versions of AAQ-SF (Sample 1, n = 2,487) and to test the discriminative validity of the selected 12-item AAQ-SF (Sample 2, n = 2,488). Data from a separate study reporting on the AAQ-24 (sample 3, n = 792) verified analyses. Results: The 12-item AAQ-SF reported adequate internal consistency in both Sample 1 (PL \u03B1 = .72, PC \u03B1 = .72, and PG \u03B1 = .62) and Sample 3 (PL \u03B1 = .68, PC \u03B1 = .73, and PG \u03B1 = .61). The AAQ-SF functioned consistently with the profile of the AAQ-24 in that subscales in both formats of this measure discriminate between respondents on key parameters such as depression, subjective health status, and overall quality of life in Sample 2. Sample 3 also demonstrated the AAQ-SF can detect the differences in attitudes toward aging between individuals experiencing anxiety and depression and those without psychological symptoms. Confirmatory Factor Analysis confirmed the structure of the AAQ-SF mirrors that of the original 24-item AAQ. Conclusions: The AAQ-SF is a robust measure of attitudes toward aging, which can reduce respondent burden when used within longer questionnaire batteries or longitudinal research.", 'call-number':"2", 'container-title':"International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry", DOI:"10/gf896x", ISSN:"0885-6230", issue:"1", language:"en", page:"113-121", source:"3.85", title:"Development of a short form of the Attitudes to Ageing Questionnaire (AAQ)", volume:"33", author:[{family:"Laidlaw", given:"Ken"}, {family:"Kishita", given:"Naoko"}, {family:"Shenkin", given:"Susan D."}, {family:"Power", given:"Michael J."}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2018", 1]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0]], []

(3)(+0000022): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"r4WUmlNj", properties:{formattedCitation:"(1995)", plainCitation:"(1995)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9677, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/884JR94P"], itemData:{id:9677, type:"article-journal", abstract:"The AGED Inventory was designed to overcome shortcomings identified in the Aging Semantic Differential, a frequently used measure of how age groups are perceived. The new instrument was developed to allow assessment both of age stereotypes and of attitudes toward age-specified targets. The Inventory was developed with data from 300 male and 300 female respondents. Two seven-item evaluative factors (the Goodness and Positiveness dimensions) resulted from a series of factor analyses used to reduce an initial set of thirty-five evaluative adjective pairs. Two seven-item descriptive factors (the Vitality and Maturity dimensions) resulted from a separate series of factor analyses used to reduce an initial set of fifty adjective pairs judged to differentiate age groups. Using confirmatory factor analyses and coefficients of congruence on data from an additional 800 respondents, the factor structures of the two evaluative factors and of the two descriptive factors were found to be replicable for young, middle-aged, and old targets assessed in either between or within subject designs. Its ease of administration, multi-dimensionality, flexibility of targets specification, and capability for assessing attitude and/or stereotype in a manner congruent with current conceptualizations of these constructs make the AGED Inventory useful in a variety of contexts.", 'container-title':"The International Journal of Aging and Human Development", DOI:"10/dt8dgk", ISSN:"0091-4150, 1541-3535", issue:"1", journalAbbreviation:"Int J Aging Hum Dev", language:"en", page:"31-55", source:"DOI.org (Crossref)", title:"The Age Group Evaluation and Description (AGED) Inventory: A New Instrument for Assessing Stereotypes of and Attitudes toward Age Groups", 'title-short':"The Age Group Evaluation and Description (AGED) Inventory", volume:"40", author:[{family:"Knox", given:"V. Jane"}, {family:"Gekoski", given:"William L."}, {family:"Kelly", given:"Lynn E."}], issued:{'date-parts':[["1995", 1]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0]], []

(3)(+0000017): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"ZjzX7wFR", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2023)", plainCitation:"(2023)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9701, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/SVZ3PLLL"], itemData:{id:9701, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Objective\nTo determine whether self-perceptions of aging (SPA) predict physical resilience following a fall and whether SPA and physical resilience affect subsequent social engagement in older adults with a fall.\nDesign\nProspective cohort study.\nSetting\nGeneral community.\nParticipants\nOlder adults who reported a fall within 2 years after baseline data collection (n=1707, mean age 72.9 years, 60.9% women).\nMain outcome measure\nPhysical resilience indicates the ability to resist or recover from functional decline from a stressor. The change in frailty status from directly after the fall to up to two years of follow-up was used to generate four physical resilience phenotypes. Social engagement was dichotomized based on the presence at one of the five social activities at least once a month. The 8-item Attitudes Toward Own Aging Scale was used to assess SPA at baseline. Multinomial logistic regression and nonlinear mediation analysis were used.\nResults\nPositive prefall SPA predicted more resilient phenotypes after a fall. Both positive SPA and physical resilience affected subsequent social engagement. Physical resilience partially mediated the association between SPA and social re-engagement (mediated percentage of 14.5\xA0%, P\u202F=\u202F0.004). This mediation effect was fully driven by those with previous falls.\nConclusion\nPositive SPA promotes physical resilience in older adults with a fall, both of which affect subsequent social engagement. Physical resilience partially mediated the effect of SPA on social engagement but only for previous fallers. Multidimensional recovery incorporating psychological, physiological and social aspects should be stressed in the rehabilitation of older adults who fall.", 'call-number':"1", 'container-title':"Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation", DOI:"10/grv49b", ISSN:"0003-9993", journalAbbreviation:"Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation", language:"en", source:"4.06", title:"Positive self-perceptions of aging increase physical resilience to facilitate social re-engagement of older adults who fall: Analysis based on Health and Retirement Study data", 'title-short':"Positive self-perceptions of aging increase physical resilience to facilitate social re-engagement of older adults who fall", URL:"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003999323001065", author:[{literal:"Zeyi Zhang"}, {literal:"Jingjing Wang"}, {literal:"Bin Ma"}, {literal:"Jingyi Wang"}, {literal:"Yuanmin Jia"}, {literal:"Ou Chen"}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2023", 3, 5]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2023", 3, 1]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0]], []

(3)(+0000074): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"8S7IepTn", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2002)", plainCitation:"(2002)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9973, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/4AC756W9"], itemData:{id:9973, type:"article-journal", abstract:"This article addresses the convergence and complementarity between self-regulatory control-process models of behavior and dynamic systems models. The control-process view holds that people have a goal in mind and try to move toward it (or away from it), monitoring the extent to which a discrepancy remains between the goal and one's present state and taking steps to reduce the discrepancy (or enlarge it). Dynamic systems models tend to emphasize a bottom-up self-organization process, in which a coherence arises from among many simultaneous influences, moving the system toward attractors and away from repellers. We suggest that these differences in emphasis reflect two facets of a more complex reality involving both types of processes. Discussion focuses on how self-organization may occur within constituent elements of a feedback system\u2014the input function, the output function, and goal values being used by the system\u2014and how feedback processes themselves can reflect self-organizing tendencies.", 'container-title':"Personality and Social Psychology Review - PERS SOC PSYCHOL REV", DOI:"10/c4sr97", journalAbbreviation:"Personality and Social Psychology Review - PERS SOC PSYCHOL REV", language:"en", source:"ResearchGate", title:"Control Processes and Self-Organization as Complementary Principles Underlying Behavior", volume:"6", author:[{family:"Carver", given:"Charles"}, {family:"Scheier", given:"Michael"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2002", 11, 1]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0]], []

(3)(+0000010): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"F0mNrMgb", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2004)", plainCitation:"(2004)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9968, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/V99PN37T"], itemData:{id:9968, type:"article-journal", abstract:"What good is self-control? We incorporated a new measure of individual differences in self-control into two large investigations of a broad spectrum of behaviors. The new scale showed good internal consistency and retest reliability. Higher scores on self-control correlated with a higher grade point average, better adjustment (fewer reports of psychopathology, higher self-esteem), less binge eating and alcohol abuse, better relationships and interpersonal skills, secure attachment, and more optimal emotional responses. Tests for curvilinearity failed to indicate any drawbacks of so-called overcontrol, and the positive effects remained after controlling for social desirability. Low self-control is thus a significant risk factor for a broad range of personal and interpersonal problems.", 'container-title':"Journal of Personality", DOI:"10/ff93z5", ISSN:"0022-3506", issue:"2", journalAbbreviation:"J Pers", language:"en", note:"PMID: 15016066", page:"271-324", source:"PubMed", title:"High self-control predicts good adjustment, less pathology, better grades, and interpersonal success", volume:"72", author:[{family:"Tangney", given:"June P."}, {family:"Baumeister", given:"Roy F."}, {family:"Boone", given:"Angie Luzio"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2004", 4]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0]], []

(3)(+0000012): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"svkRUhyt", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2014)", plainCitation:"(2014)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9982, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/46WYRPYM"], itemData:{id:9982, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Self-control refers to the mental processes that allow people to override thoughts and emotions, thus enabling behavior to vary adaptively from moment to moment. Dominating contemporary research on this topic is the viewpoint that self-control relies upon a limited resource, such that engaging in acts of restraint depletes this inner capacity and undermines subsequent attempts at control (i.e., ego depletion). Noting theoretical and empirical problems with this view, here we advance a competing model that develops a non-resource-based account of self-control. We suggest that apparent regulatory failures reflect the motivated switching of task priorities as people strive to strike an optimal balance between engaging cognitive labor to pursue \u2018have-to\u2019 goals versus preferring cognitive leisure in the pursuit of \u2018want-to\u2019 goals.", 'call-number':"1", 'container-title':"Trends in Cognitive Sciences", DOI:"10/ggdgb4", ISSN:"1364-6613", issue:"3", journalAbbreviation:"Trends in Cognitive Sciences", language:"en", page:"127-133", source:"24.482", title:"Why self-control seems (but may not be) limited", volume:"18", author:[{family:"Inzlicht", given:"Michael"}, {family:"Schmeichel", given:"Brandon J."}, {family:"Macrae", given:"C. Leicester\u8BBF\u95EE\u6559\u6388\u3002\u5148\u540E\u5728\u56FD\u5185\u5916\u5B66\u672F\u671F\u520A\u4E0A\u53D1\u8868\u8BBA\u658780\u4F59\u7BC7\uFF0C\u51FA\u7248\u4E13\u8457\u3001\u8BD1\u8457\u53CA\u4E3B\u7F16\u6216\u53C2\u7F16\u5B66\u672F\u8457\u4F5C\u6216\u6559\u675010\u4F59\u90E8\uFF0C\u83B7\u5F97\u5168\u56FD\u6559\u80B2\u79D1\u5B66\u7814\u7A76\u4F18\u79C0\u6210\u679C\u5956\u3001\u5168\u56FD\u6559\u80B2\u56FE\u4E66\u5956\u3001\u6E56\u5317\u7701\u793E\u4F1A\u79D1\u5B66\u4F18\u79C0\u6210\u679C\u5956\u3001\u6E56\u5317\u7701\u4F18\u79C0\u6559\u5E08\u3001\u6E56\u5317\u7701\u6559\u5B66\u6210\u679C\u5956\u7B49\u591A\u9879\u5956\u52B1\u3002\n\u8D3A\u91D1\u6CE2\uFF0C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u535A\u58EB\uFF0C\u534E\u4E2D\u5E08\u8303\u5927\u5B66\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u9662\u8BB2\u5E08\uFF0C\u7855\u58EB\u751F\u5BFC\u5E08\u3002\u4E3B\u8981\u7814\u7A76\u9886\u57DF\uFF1A\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u548C\u8BA4\u77E5\u795E\u7ECF\u79D1\u5B66\u3002\u4E3B\u8981\u7814\u7A76\u5174\u8DA3\uFF1A\u4EBA\u683C\u7684\u751F\u7406\u57FA\u7840\u3001\u7F51\u7EDC\u6210\u763E\u7684\u8111\u673A\u5236\u3001\u4EBA\u7684\u524D\u6CE8\u610F\u52A0\u5DE5\u8111\u673A\u5236\u3001\u5FC3\u7406\u8FDB\u5316\u7684\u795E\u7ECF\u673A\u5236\u7B49\u3002\u5728SCI\u548CSSCI\u6536\u5F55\u520A\u7269\u4EE5\u53CA\u56FD\u5185\u591A\u79CD\u6838\u5FC3\u671F\u520A\u53D1\u8868\u8BBA\u658710\u4F59\u7BC7\uFF0C\u53C2\u7F16\u548C\u53C2\u8BD1\u5B66\u672F\u8457\u4F5C4\u90E8\u3002\n\n\u5185\u5BB9\u7B80\u4ECB:\n\u300A\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u300B\u4EE5\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u7684\u516D\u5927\u7406\u8BBA\u548C\u4E09\u5927\u4E3B\u9898\u4E3A\u5B66\u79D1\u57FA\u672C\u67B6\u6784\u3002\u516D\u5927\u7406\u8BBA\u5305\u62EC\u7279\u8D28\u7406\u8BBA\u3001\u751F\u7269\u5B66\u7406\u8BBA\u3001\u7CBE\u795E\u5206\u6790\u3001\u884C\u4E3A\u4E3B\u4E49\u3001\u4EBA\u672C\u4E3B\u4E49\u548C\u8BA4\u77E5\u4E0E\u793E\u4F1A\u8BA4\u77E5\u7406\u8BBA\uFF0C\u4E09\u5927\u4E3B\u9898\u5305\u62EC\u4EBA\u683C\u8868\u73B0\uFF08demonstration\uFF09\u3001\u4EBA\u683C\u52A8\u529B\uFF08dynamics\uFF09\u548C\u4EBA\u683C\u53D1\u5C55\uFF08development\uFF09\uFF0C\u5408\u8D77\u6765\u5C31\u662F\u7406\u8BBA\uFF08theorie8\uFF09\u52A0\u201C3D\u201D\uFF08\u6216\u201CT\uFF063D\u201D\uFF09\u67B6\u6784\u3002\u4E09\u5927\u4E3B\u9898\u4E0D\u4EC5\u8D2F\u7A7F\u4E8E\u516D\u5927\u7406\u8BBA\uFF0C\u800C\u4E14\u4F53\u73B0\u5728\u4E30\u5BCC\u7684\u5177\u4F53\u7814\u7A76\u4E2D\u3002\u8FD9\u79CD\u67B6\u6784\u662F\u4E00\u79CD\u6574\u5408\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u4E3B\u8981\u7406\u8BBA\u548C\u4E13\u9898\u7814\u7A76\u6210\u679C\u7684\u5C1D\u8BD5\uFF0C\u4F53\u73B0\u4E86\u8FD9\u4E00\u9886\u57DF\u4ECE\u7406\u8BBA\u6D41\u6D3E\u7684\u7EB7\u4E89\u5230\u6DF1\u5165\u7684\u4E13\u9898\u7814\u7A76\u7684\u91CD\u5927\u8F6C\u5411\u3002\n\u300A\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u300B\u5199\u4F5C\u98CE\u683C\u7B80\u660E\u6D41\u7545\uFF0C\u9002\u5408\u672C\u79D1\u751F\u6216\u4EE5\u5B66\u4E60\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u57FA\u672C\u77E5\u8BC6\u4E3A\u76EE\u6807\u7684\u8BFB\u8005\u3002", ISBN:"978-7-04-031279-9", language:"zh", note:"\u300A\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u300B;\uD83D\uDC69\u200D\u2696\uFE0F22;\uD83D\uDD1F8.2;39.60 \u5143;", 'number-of-pages':"427", publisher:"\u9AD8\u7B49\u6559\u80B2\u51FA\u7248\u793E", source:"Douban", title:"\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66", 'title-short':"\u300A\u4EBA\u683C\u5FC3\u7406\u5B66\u300B", URL:"https://book.douban.com/subject/6397699/", author:[{family:"\u90ED\u6C38\u7389\uFF0C\u8D3A\u91D1\u6CE2", given:""}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2023", 3, 7]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2011", 4]]}}, locator:"235-236", label:"page"}, {id:6170, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/ZSB8ZNFF"], itemData:{id:6170, type:"thesis", abstract:"Nowadays, the development process of aging in our country is accelerating, and depression, loneliness and other elderly mental issues have become increasingly prominent. Psychological attention and research is required in elderly.2-way social support of elderly includes providing support and receiving support, Previous studies have shown that social support and the sense of self-control are important variables to predict the mental health of the elderly. This study aims to explore the characteristics of the ageds\u20192-way social support and the sense of self-control, and the relationships between the two variables.This study used questionnaires and in-depth interview research. In the survey:First, Translating English 2-way social support scale as a tool, testing the applicability of the scale of the elderly population in China; and further revising the \"sense of self-control questionnaire of the elderly\".Subsequently, in the old center, parks, nursing homes and old university of Nanjing to sample survey, and obtained 472 valid questionnaires, then using SPSS 16.0 to analysis the data.In the process of interview, by using aim sample method,10 elderly was selected as interview subjects, and 1.5-2 hours interview were conducted with each interviewee. With their permission, the researcher recorded each conversation. Transcribed all tape-recorded sound into texts, combined with observations, the researcher collated and analyzed the data, Including the procedures of reading, explaining, landing, coding, categorizing, analyzing and writing. Combining two part study, the main conclusions are drawn as follows:\uFF081\uFF09 the overall level of the ageds\u20192-way social support is high;its total score, receive emotion support, receive tool support, provide emotion support and provide tool support have significant differences in age, education, income and health level. The elderly generally pursue the principle of reciprocity in their social support, but there are some differences among support with a spouse, children and friends, and it is divided into \"stay together type\", \"seek independent type\" and \"equality and mutual benefit type\", the aged\u2019s social support mainly is emotional support, and tool support is aide. The aged\u2019s social support from family and friends circle complemented each other.\uFF082\uFF09 The overall level of elderly\u2019s sense of self-control is upper the middle, and it consists of five dimensions:sense of cognitive control, sense of emotional control, sense of daily life control, sense of health control and sense of interpersonal control, and the score of cognitive control is lower.elderly women is active in daily life, so their sense of daily life control is significant higher than elderly men. The elderly pay close attention on keeping healthy, active in exercise, and trying to control their own lives.\uFF083\uFF09 The 2-way social support of elderly can significant predict their sense of control level; providing emotional support and providing tool support have high power of explanatory, receiving emotional support lower, and receiving tool support haven\u2019t enter equation. This is because providing social support reflects the elderly\u2019s need of self-worth, and promote the sense of self-control; and receiving social support promote or hinder the sense of self-control, the key is whether it make the elderly have sense of guilty and burden.", genre:"\u7855\u58EB", language:"zh-CN", publisher:"\u5357\u4EAC\u5E08\u8303\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u53CC\u5411\u793E\u4F1A\u652F\u6301\u4E0E\u81EA\u6211\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u5173\u7CFB\u7814\u7A76", uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/Z3W26GLS"], itemData:{id:9751, type:"thesis", abstract:"\u7814\u7A76\u80CC\u666F\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u5DF2\u7ECF\u6210\u4E3A\u793E\u4F1A\u5171\u540C\u5173\u6CE8\u7684\u95EE\u9898\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u8BA4\u4E3A,\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u4E0E\u4EBA\u683C\u56E0\u7D20\u6709\u7740\u5BC6\u5207\u7684\u5173\u7CFB,\u800C\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4F5C\u4E3A\u4E2A\u4F53\u76F8\u5BF9\u7A33\u5B9A\u7684\u4EBA\u683C\u8BA4\u77E5\u56E0\u7D20\u662F\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u8EAB\u5FC3\u5065\u5EB7\u7684\u91CD\u8981\u4FDD\u62A4\u6027\u56E0\u7D20\u3002\u4E0E\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u7684\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4FA7\u91CD\u4E8E\u53CD\u6620\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5BF9\u81EA\u6211\u5065\u5EB7\u63A7\u5236\u7684\u4FE1\u5FF5,\u5B83\u53EF\u4EE5\u5F71\u54CD\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u81EA\u6211\u62A4\u7406\u7684\u4FE1\u5FC3\u53CA\u80FD\u529B,\u4ECE\u800C\u5F71\u54CD\u5176\u8EAB\u5FC3\u72B6\u51B5\u548C\u751F\u6D3B\u8D28\u91CF\u3002\u56E0\u6B64\u6B63\u786E\u8BC4\u4F30\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F,\u5206\u6790\u76F8\u5173\u5F71\u54CD\u56E0\u7D20,\u5BF9\u5E2E\u52A9\u3001\u6307\u5BFC\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u8DF5\u884C\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u5177\u6709\u91CD\u8981\u610F\u4E49\u3002\u76EE\u524D\u56FD\u5185\u5916\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u7814\u7A76\u591A\u96C6\u4E2D\u4E8E\u5BF9\u4E00\u822C\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u6216\u7279\u5B9A\u9886\u57DF\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u8FDB\u884C\u8BC4\u4F30,\u800C\u5BF9\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u8BC4\u4F30\u76F8\u5BF9\u8F83\u5C11,\u4E14\u5BF9\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u8BC4\u4F30\u5DE5\u5177\u7684\u7814\u7A76\u591A\u91C7\u7528\u4E00\u822C\u4EBA\u7FA4\u7684\u666E\u9002\u6027\u95EE\u5377,\u5C11\u89C1\u4E13\u7528\u4E8E\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u8BC4\u4F30\u5DE5\u5177\u3002Claassens,L.\u535A\u58EB\u7814\u5236\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377,\u4E13\u7528\u4E8E\u8BC4\u4F30\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F,\u4E14\u5177\u6709\u826F\u597D\u7684\u4FE1\u6548\u5EA6,\u76EE\u524D\u56FD\u5185\u5C1A\u672A\u53D1\u73B0\u8BE5\u95EE\u5377\u7684\u6C49\u5316\u53CA\u5E94\u7528\u7814\u7A76\u7684\u62A5\u9053\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u76EE\u7684\u5F15\u8FDB\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377,\u5F62\u6210\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377,\u8BC4\u4EF7\u5176\u4FE1\u6548\u5EA6;\u5E94\u7528\u8BE5\u95EE\u5377\u8FDB\u884C\u5B9E\u6D4B,\u8C03\u67E5\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u63A7\u5236\u6C34\u5E73\u53CA\u76F8\u5173\u5F71\u54CD\u56E0\u7D20,\u4E3A\u63D0\u9AD8\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u5E72\u9884\u63D0\u4F9B\u53C2\u8003\u4F9D\u636E\u3002\u65B9\u6CD51.\u901A\u8FC7\u7FFB\u8BD1\u3001\u56DE\u8BD1\u3001\u6587\u5316\u8C03\u9002\u53CA\u9884\u8BD5\u9A8C\u5F62\u6210\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377\u3002\u91C7\u7528\u65B9\u4FBF\u62BD\u6837\u6CD5\u4E8E2017\u5E746\uFF5E9\u6708,\u62BD\u53D6\u5E7F\u5DDE\u5E02\u67D0\u517B\u8001\u9662\u7684315\u540D\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u3002\u91C7\u7528\u9879\u76EE\u5206\u6790\u3001\u5185\u90E8\u4E00\u81F4\u6027\u3001\u91CD\u6D4B\u4FE1\u5EA6\u3001\u5185\u5BB9\u6548\u5EA6\u3001\u6548\u6807\u5173\u8054\u6548\u5EA6\u53CA\u63A2\u7D22\u6027\u56E0\u5B50\u5206\u6790\u5BF9\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u95EE\u5377\u8FDB\u884C\u4FE1\u6548\u5EA6\u68C0\u9A8C\u30022.2017\u5E746\uFF5E11\u6708,\u91C7\u7528\u4FBF\u5229\u62BD\u6837\u7684\u65B9\u6CD5,\u5728\u5E7F\u5DDE\u5E02\u67D0\u517B\u8001\u9662\u53CA2\u4E2A\u793E\u533A\u7684504\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E2D\u5E94\u7528\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377\u8FDB\u884C\u5B9E\u6D4B\u3002\u5206\u6790\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u6C34\u5E73\u53CA\u4E0E\u4E00\u822C\u4EBA\u53E3\u5B66\u8D44\u6599\u53CA\u751F\u6D3B\u8D28\u91CF\u7684\u5173\u7CFB\u3002\u7ED3\u679C1.\u6C49\u5316\u540E\u7684\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377\u517128\u4E2A\u6761\u76EE,\u5177\u6709\u826F\u597D\u7684\u533A\u5206\u5EA6;\u603B\u95EE\u5377Cronbach's genre:"\u7855\u58EB", language:"zh", publisher:"\u5357\u65B9\u533B\u79D1\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u4E2D\u6587\u7248\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377\u7684\u4FE1\u6548\u5EA6\u68C0\u9A8C\u53CA\u5E94\u7528", URL:"https://oversea.cnki.net/KCMS/detail/detail.aspx?dbcode=CMFD&dbname=CMFD201901&filename=1018276493.nh&uniplatform=OVERSEA&v=IkPEYVTbjQN7OENuzni972YH9vPIqb44INTl9U1TTM7J_v0zvxDkIk7Xu1us-lbW", author:[{literal:"\u5468\u4E9A\u661F"}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2023", 3, 6]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2018"]]}}, label:"page"}, {id:9783, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/TB65N9AT"], itemData:{id:9783, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Aim. This paper is a report of a theoretically based review of literature exploring the concept of perceived control in relation to older adults. Background. Perceived control is a cognitive attribute that is a precursor to function, a mediator between social support and psychological wellbeing, and instrumental for effective disease self-management. It has been defined from several theoretical perspectives with either a global or a specific focus. Methods. A review of literature was conducted. Articles were abstracted into a table in order to compare the purpose, theoretical framework, definition of perceived control, scope of application of perceived control, research questions, subjects, methods, instruments and findings across studies. The articles were sorted by theoretical framework for analyses among and between theoretical frameworks. Results. Twenty papers published between 1995 and 2005, listed in CINAHL or Medline, with the words \u2018perceived control\u2019 in the title, and which included older adults as at least half of the sample and used one of five predominant theoretical frameworks were included in a review of the literature. In this review, perceived control is defined within the theories of social learning, self-efficacy, planned behaviour, the lifespan theory of control, and from a person\u2013environment framework. There is little consensus among researchers as to the definition of perceived control. Conclusion. Lack of consensus on the theoretical underpinnings and variability in definition of perceived control exist. The mechanisms through which perceived control develops and is exercised are also in dispute. Nevertheless, there is general agreement that high perceived control is important for wellbeing in older adults.", 'call-number':"3", 'container-title':"Journal of Advanced Nursing", DOI:"10/c97jqk", ISSN:"1365-2648", issue:"1", language:"en", note:"_eprint: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/j.1365-2648.2007.04320.x", page:"1-10", source:"3.057", title:"Theoretical perspectives of perceived control in older adults: a selective review of the literature", 'title-short':"Theoretical perspectives of perceived control in older adults", volume:"59", author:[{family:"Jacelon", given:"Cynthia S."}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2007"]]}}}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0]], []

(3)(+0000095): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"5BGIIMsX", properties:{formattedCitation:"(Baumeister et al., 2007)", plainCitation:"(Baumeister et al., 2007)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9978, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/LSMLAR37"], itemData:{id:9978, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Self-control is a central function of the self and an important key to success in life. The exertion of self-control appears to depend on a limited resource. Just as a muscle gets tired from exertion, acts of self-control cause short-term impairments (ego depletion) in subsequent self-control, even on unrelated tasks. Research has supported the strength model in the domains of eating, drinking, spending, sexuality, intelligent thought, making choices, and interpersonal behavior. Motivational or framing factors can temporarily block the deleterious effects of being in a state of ego depletion. Blood glucose is an important component of the energy.", 'container-title':"Current Directions in Psychological Science", DOI:"10/ctkttv", journalAbbreviation:"Current Directions in Psychological Science", language:"en", page:"351-355", source:"ResearchGate", title:"The Strength Model of Self-Control", volume:"16", author:[{family:"Baumeister", given:"Roy"}, {family:"Vohs", given:"Kathleen"}, {family:"Tice", given:"Dianne"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2007", 12, 1]]}}}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0]], []

itemData:{id:6165, type:"article-journal", abstract:"\u76EE\u7684:\u63A2\u8BA8\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4E0E\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u95F4\u5173\u7CFB\u3002\u65B9\u6CD5:\u91C7\u7528\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u91CF\u8868\u3001\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u95EE\u5377,\u901A\u8FC7\u65B9\u4FBF\u53D6\u6837\u4E0E\u5165\u6237\u8BBF\u95EE\u7ED3\u5408\u7684\u65B9\u5F0F\u5BF9250\u540D60\u5C81\u53CA\u4EE5\u4E0A\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u8FDB\u884C\u95EE\u5377\u8C03\u67E5\u3002\u7ED3\u679C:1\u7537\u6027\u6BD4\u5973\u6027\u66F4\u53EF\u80FD\u5B9E\u73B0\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316,\u7FA4\u5C45\u3001\u8F83\u9AD8\u7684\u6587\u5316\u6C34\u5E73\u548C\u6708\u9000\u4F11\u91D1\u6709\u52A9\u4E8E\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316,\u968F\u7740\u5E74\u9F84\u7684\u589E\u957F\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5B9E\u73B0\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u7684\u53EF\u80FD\u6027\u964D\u4F4E;2\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u548C\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u5448\u663E\u8457\u6B63\u76F8\u5173\u3002\u7ED3\u8BBA:\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u5BF9\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u6709\u76F4\u63A5\u7684\u5F71\u54CD,\u8FD9\u4E00\u7ED3\u679C\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u8D28\u91CF\u7684\u63D0\u5347\u4E0E\u79EF\u6781\u8001\u5316\u7684\u5B9E\u73B0\u6709\u91CD\u8981\u610F\u4E49\u3002", 'container-title':"\u79D1\u6559\u6587\u6C47(\u4E0A\u65EC\u520A)", ISSN:"1672-7894", issue:"5", language:"zh-CN", page:"182-183", source:"CNKI", title:"\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4E0E\u6210\u529F\u8001\u5316\u7684\u5173\u7CFB\u7814\u7A76", author:[{literal:"\u7FC1\u5A07"}, {literal:"\u6797\u826F\u7AE0"}, {literal:"\u7F2A\u6653\u5170"}, {literal:"\u674E\u83F2\u73CD"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2015"]]}}}, {id:6170, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/ZSB8ZNFF"], itemData:{id:6170, type:"thesis", abstract:"Nowadays, the development process of aging in our country is accelerating, and depression, loneliness and other elderly mental issues have become increasingly prominent. Psychological attention and research is required in elderly.2-way social support of elderly includes providing support and receiving support, Previous studies have shown that social support and the sense of self-control are important variables to predict the mental health of the elderly. This study aims to explore the characteristics of the ageds\u20192-way social support and the sense of self-control, and the relationships between the two variables.This study used questionnaires and in-depth interview research. In the survey:First, Translating English 2-way social support scale as a tool, testing the applicability of the scale of the elderly population in China; and further revising the \"sense of self-control questionnaire of the elderly\".Subsequently, in the old center, parks, nursing homes and old university of Nanjing to sample survey, and obtained 472 valid questionnaires, then using SPSS 16.0 to analysis the data.In the process of interview, by using aim sample method,10 elderly was selected as interview subjects, and 1.5-2 hours interview were conducted with each interviewee. With their permission, the researcher recorded each conversation. Transcribed all tape-recorded sound into texts, combined with observations, the researcher collated and analyzed the data, Including the procedures of reading, explaining, landing, coding, categorizing, analyzing and writing. Combining two part study, the main conclusions are drawn as follows:\uFF081\uFF09 the overall level of the ageds\u20192-way social support is high;its total score, receive emotion support, receive tool support, provide emotion support and provide tool support have significant differences in age, education, income and health level. The elderly generally pursue the principle of reciprocity in their social support, but there are some differences among support with a spouse, children and friends, and it is divided into \"stay together type\", \"seek independent type\" and \"equality and mutual benefit type\", the aged\u2019s social support mainly is emotional support, and tool support is aide. The aged\u2019s social support from family and friends circle complemented each other.\uFF082\uFF09 The overall level of elderly\u2019s sense of self-control is upper the middle, and it consists of five dimensions:sense of cognitive control, sense of emotional control, sense of daily life control, sense of health control and sense of interpersonal control, and the score of cognitive control is lower.elderly women is active in daily life, so their sense of daily life control is significant higher than elderly men. The elderly pay close attention on keeping healthy, active in exercise, and trying to control their own lives.\uFF083\uFF09 The 2-way social support of elderly can significant predict their sense of control level; providing emotional support and providing tool support have high power of explanatory, receiving emotional support lower, and receiving tool support haven\u2019t enter equation. This is because providing social support reflects the elderly\u2019s need of self-worth, and promote the sense of self-control; and receiving social support promote or hinder the sense of self-control, the key is whether it make the elderly have sense of guilty and burden.", genre:"\u7855\u58EB", language:"zh-CN", publisher:"\u5357\u4EAC\u5E08\u8303\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u53CC\u5411\u793E\u4F1A\u652F\u6301\u4E0E\u81EA\u6211\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u5173\u7CFB\u7814\u7A76", URL:"https://oversea.cnki.net/kcms/detail/detail.aspx?dbcode=CMFD&dbname=CMFD201701&filename=1016304233.nh&uniplatform=NZKPT&v=S2nSL_vaqyknriWnnArtCBUUqmAFfu8GPxVAPEmVigAdUYSMk5Gy9_WrybI_VM4F", author:[{literal:"\u5F90\u7F8E\u541B"}], contributor:[{literal:"\u6768\u8389\u840D"}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2022", 5, 29]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2015"]]}}}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0], ["5BGIIMsX", 0]], []

(3)(+0000010): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"ig9ZmkEh", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2008)", plainCitation:"(2008)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9966, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/RSKCCIJJ"], itemData:{id:9966, type:"article-journal", abstract:"This empirical study investigated three mechanisms of protection (preventive, compensatory, buffering) for two factors (emotional social support, sense of personal control) in the relationship between exposure to community violence and psychological distress among 947 diverse, older adolescents. Findings indicate that social support and sense of personal control do provide protection; however, the primary mechanism is compensatory (for support r = -.35; for control, r = -.48). Support but not control serves a preventive function (r = -.11). Neither variable protects via buffering-the mechanisms most commonly discussed in the literature. Protection is not a simple straightforward process.", 'container-title':"Adolescence", ISSN:"0001-8449", issue:"172", journalAbbreviation:"Adolescence", language:"en", note:"PMID: 19149141", page:"693-712", source:"PubMed", title:"Community violence and psychological distress: the protective effects of emotional social support and sense of personal control among older adolescents", 'title-short':"Community violence and psychological distress", volume:"43", author:[{family:"Rosenthal", given:"Beth Spenciner"}, {family:"Wilson", given:"W. Cody"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2008"]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0], ["5BGIIMsX", 0], ["G7rn9VqG", 0]], []

(3)(+0000032): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"pQ9KSiwP", properties:{formattedCitation:"(1978)", plainCitation:"(1978)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9990, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/86QUCY9A"], itemData:{id:9990, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Coping refers to behavior that protects people from being psychologically harmed by problematic social experience, a behavior that importantly mediates the impact that societies have on their members. The protective function of coping behavior can be exercised in 3 ways: by eliminating or modifying conditions giving rise to problems; by perceptually controlling the meaning of experience in a manner that neutralizes its problematic character; and by keeping the emotional consequences of problems within manageable bounds. The efficacy of a number of concrete coping behaviors representing these 3 functions was evaluated. Results indicate that individuals' coping interventions are most effective when dealing with problems within the close interpersonal role areas of marriage and child-rearing and least effective when dealing with the more impersonal problems found in occupation. The effective coping modes are unequally distributed in society, with men, the educated, and the affluent making greater use of the efficacious mechanisms.", 'container-title':"Journal of health and social behavior", DOI:"10/fvkk4g", journalAbbreviation:"Journal of health and social behavior", language:"en", page:"2-21", source:"ResearchGate", title:"The Structure of Coping", volume:"19", author:[{family:"Pearlin", given:"Leonard"}, {family:"Schooler", given:"Carmi"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["1978", 4, 1]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0], ["5BGIIMsX", 0], ["G7rn9VqG", 0], ["ig9ZmkEh", 0], ["T5cGQRup", 0], ["HQGCinnx", 0]], []

(3)(+0000020): Mod time for 1/GUHU8LJ3 matches remote file -- skipping

(4)(+0000000): Checking attachment file for item 1/GUQ85PDK

(3)(+0000009): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"hneSqm8K", properties:{formattedCitation:"(Drewelies et al., 2017; Wiest et al., 2013)", plainCitation:"(Drewelies et al., 2017; Wiest et al., 2013)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:6204, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/ZAG4SIPS"], itemData:{id:6204, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Perceived control is a key component of successful aging and may serve as a protective factor against age-related declines in central domains of functioning. However, it is a largely open question whether and how perceived control changes from midadulthood to very old age and how such change is shaped by health and social contexts. To examine these questions, we apply growth models to up to 15-year 4-wave longitudinal data from the German Ageing Survey (DEAS; N = 10,081; aged 40-85 years at baseline; 49% women). Results revealed that perceived control is relatively stable in midlife, but starts to decline after midlife. Starting at 70, perceived control declines an average of a quarter of a SD per 10 years. Suffering from comorbidity and functional limitations were each associated with considerably lower perceived control. Volunteering and less loneliness were each uniquely associated with higher perceived control, over and above the other social factors as well as sociodemographic and health variables. Surprisingly, less social support was associated with stronger perceived control. We also found significant interaction effects suggesting that the combination of functional limitations with older age and loneliness with lower education were each associated with particularly compromised perceived control. Overall we found little evidence for correlates of change in perceived control, with only the loneliness-control association becoming slightly weaker over time. We take our findings to suggest that various different facets of social integration later in life are uniquely relevant for perceived control and suggest routes for further inquiry. We incorporated a new measure of individual differences in self-control into two large investigations of a broad spectrum of behaviors. The new scale showed good internal consistency and retest reliability. Higher scores on self-control correlated with a higher grade point average, better adjustment (fewer reports of psychopathology, higher self-esteem), less binge eating and alcohol abuse, better relationships and interpersonal skills, secure attachment, and more optimal emotional responses. Tests for curvilinearity failed to indicate any drawbacks of so-called overcontrol, and the positive effects remained after controlling for social desirability. (3)(+0000013): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"ebqt30vf", properties:{formattedCitation:"(G\\uc0\\u252{}rdere et al., 2022; Nilsen et al., 2020; Pilarska & Baumeister, 2018; Unger et al., 2016)", plainCitation:"(G\xFCrdere et al., 2022; Nilsen et al., 2020; Pilarska & Baumeister, 2018; Unger et al., 2016)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:10025, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/KX52KR86"], itemData:{id:10025, type:"article-journal", abstract:"The Brief Self-Control Scale (BSCS) developed by Tangney, Baumeister, and Boone (2004) is a widely used measure of trait self-control. The present study aimed to validate Italian version of the BSCS. 262 Italian university students completed BSCS along with measures of grit, impulsive behavior, self-esteem, resilience, and psychological distress. 143 of the first sample completed BSCS after three weeks again. Results indicated that the Italian version of the BSCS is one-dimensional as the original BSCS. Good internal consistency and test-retest stability were documented. Convergent and divergent validity of the construct was established with the association between BSCS and measures of grit and impulsive behavior. Furthermore, predictive validity assessment showed that BSCS positively predicted self-esteem and resilience, and negatively predicted psychological distress as expected. In conclusion, findings suggest that the Italian BSCS is a reliable and valid instrument assessing trait self-control in Italian speaking populations.", 'container-title':"Journal of Evidence-Based Psychotherapies", DOI:"10/grwddc", ISSN:"23600853, 23600853", issue:"2", journalAbbreviation:"JEBP", language:"en", page:"103-114", source:"DOI.org (Crossref)", title:"The Italian Validation of the Brief Self-Control Scale: A Preliminary Analysis", 'title-short':"The Italian Validation of the Brief Self-Control Scale", volume:"22", author:[{family:"G\xFCrdere", given:"Ceren"}, {family:"Bottesi", given:"Gioia"}, {family:"Pfeffer", given:"Ines"}, {family:"Carraro", given:"Eleonora"}, {family:"Ghisi", given:"Marta"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2022", 9, 1]]}}, label:"page"}, {id:10026, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/UMK2FQH7"], itemData:{id:10026, type:"article-journal", 'container-title':"Psychological Assessment", DOI:"10/ghdqnn", ISSN:"1939-134X, 1040-3590", issue:"11", journalAbbreviation:"Psychological Assessment", language:"en", page:"1057-1074", source:"DOI.org (Crossref)", title:"The Multidimensional Self-Control Scale (MSCS): Development and validation.", 'title-short':"The Multidimensional Self-Control Scale (MSCS)", volume:"32", author:[{family:"Nilsen", given:"Fredrik A."}, {family:"Bang", given:"Henning"}, {family:"Boe", given:"Ole"}, {family:"Martinsen", given:"\xD8yvind Lund"}, {family:"Lang-Ree", given:"Ole Christian"}, {family:"R\xF8ysamb", given:"Espen"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2020", 11]]}}}, {id:10013, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/TJNPP2XK"], itemData:{id:10013, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Theory and research have both characterized self-control as a vital human strength. Tangney, Baumeister, and Boone\u2019s (2004) Self-Control Scale (SCS) is a 36-item self-report questionnaire that assess individual differences in multiple aspects of self-control. The scale is now considered the preeminent measure of self-control in social and psychological research. This article presents studies that evaluated: (a) the psychometric properties of the Polish version of the SCS, and (b) whether higher SCS scores correlated with positive outcomes in Poland. A total of 441 Polish university students took part in the studies. Psychometrically, the Polish SCS proved to be reasonably sound, with good internal consistency (\u03B1 = .89). Correlations with criteria measures showed that both full and brief self-control scores were positively related to self-esteem, perspective taking, and guilt-proneness, while negatively related to personal distress, proneness to shame, externalization, and unconcern. High self-control was also associated with being conscientious, emotionally stable, and open. It is concluded that the Polish SCS offers a viable option for assessing trait self-control and for studying its relationship with a broad spectrum of psychological and social variables.", 'container-title':"Polish Psychological Bulletin", DOI:"10/grwdc3", journalAbbreviation:"Polish Psychological Bulletin", language:"en", page:"95\u2013106", source:"ResearchGate", title:"Psychometric properties and correlates of the Polish version of the Self-Control Scale (SCS)", volume:"49", author:[{family:"Pilarska", given:"Aleksandra"}, {family:"Baumeister", given:"Roy"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2018", 4, 1]]}}}, {id:10019, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/F3PKXKY9"], itemData:{id:10019, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Recent studies have characterized self-control as a vital psychological variable that helps explain various problems. Tangney's Self-Control Scale (SCS) is a self-report measurement to assess individual differences in traits of self-control. It has gained popularity in social and psychological science research. In China, there are a few Chinese-version scales measuring general self-control, which can be applied to college students. The purposes of the present study were to evaluate: (a) the psychometric properties of the Chinese version of Tangney's SCS using confirmatory factor analysis, and (b) whether higher scores on the scale correlated with positive outcomes in China. The final sample in this study consisted of 371 Chinese college students aged 17-23 years. The Full SCS and Brief SCS were both found to have a reasonable fitness, which also had satisfactory internal consistencies and a high correlation. Higher scores on the SCS correlated with higher self-esteem, extraversion, better harmony in interpersonal relationships and an appropriate anger expression, less impulsiveness, and state and trait anger. The test-retest reliability was confirmed in two additional samples. Tangney's SCS could be used in China.", 'container-title':"PsyCh journal", DOI:"10/ggsf2p", journalAbbreviation:"PsyCh journal", language:"en", source:"ResearchGate", title:"The revising of the Tangney Self-Control Scale for Chinese students", volume:"5", author:[{family:"Unger", given:"Alexander"}, {family:"Bi", given:"Chongzeng"}, {family:"Xiao", given:"Ying-Ying"}, {family:"Ybarra", given:"Oscar"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2016", 5, 4]]}}}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0], ["5BGIIMsX", 0], ["G7rn9VqG", 0], ["ig9ZmkEh", 0], ["T5cGQRup", 0], ["HQGCinnx", 0], ["pQ9KSiwP", 0], ["1RCgmfGw", 0], ["hneSqm8K", 0], ["njlgbCxp", 0]], []

(3)(+0000019): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"kduANWRE", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2016)", plainCitation:"(2016)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:10019, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/F3PKXKY9"], itemData:{id:10019, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Recent studies have characterized self-control as a vital psychological variable that helps explain various problems. Tangney's Self-Control Scale (SCS) is a self-report measurement to assess individual differences in traits of self-control. It has gained popularity in social and psychological science research. In China, there are a few Chinese-version scales measuring general self-control, which can be applied to college students. The purposes of the present study were to evaluate: (a) the psychometric properties of the Chinese version of Tangney's SCS using confirmatory factor analysis, and (b) whether higher scores on the scale correlated with positive outcomes in China. The final sample in this study consisted of 371 Chinese college students aged 17-23 years. The Full SCS and Brief SCS were both found to have a reasonable fitness, which also had satisfactory internal consistencies and a high correlation. Higher scores on the SCS correlated with higher self-esteem, extraversion, better harmony in interpersonal relationships and an appropriate anger expression, less impulsiveness, and state and trait anger. The test-retest reliability was confirmed in two additional samples. Tangney's SCS could be used in China.", 'container-title':"PsyCh journal", DOI:"10/ggsf2p", journalAbbreviation:"PsyCh journal", language:"en", source:"ResearchGate", title:"The revising of the Tangney Self-Control Scale for Chinese students", volume:"5", author:[{family:"Unger", given:"Alexander"}, {family:"Bi", given:"Chongzeng"}, {family:"Xiao", given:"Ying-Ying"}, {family:"Ybarra", given:"Oscar"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2016", 5, 4]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), [["A4SHl5yv", 0], ["NK6Aj9WV", 0], ["CBvbM7oh", 0], ["4vvEuvf0", 0], ["OY7za2Sy", 0], ["mKIiUF6J", 0], ["owELccFI", 0], ["MFGgZDMv", 0], ["m2aDgFWB", 0], ["JepMTqoO", 0], ["Q5cmNGcy", 0], ["vCjZUc9l", 0], ["osGsKPLA", 0], ["OLZgiFzK", 0], ["0EX9jN8M", 0], ["jENgfQda", 0], ["XdiFK1R3", 0], ["uXnA5ttT", 0], ["JqaKepWR", 0], ["Y4jafsHn", 0], ["ezH313WA", 0], ["cVQkBJXI", 0], ["4Xr1Yav2", 0], ["2mVckB5l", 0], ["XH7UXShj", 0], ["pfT4aYdw", 0], ["QFK7RoT1", 0], ["r4WUmlNj", 0], ["n5wNc7iT", 0], ["VijMiCnY", 0], ["QlL6P7hF", 0], ["oSAG5Koc", 0], ["80jZPSWd", 0], ["UrpWskc0", 0], ["7IT5Krx1", 0], ["ZjzX7wFR", 0], ["cWOc6UFt", 0], ["jNbh5Vma", 0], ["vIbEPSD2", 0], ["8S7IepTn", 0], ["cVtsaePV", 0], ["F0mNrMgb", 0], ["svkRUhyt", 0], ["eqABAQCk", 0], ["5BGIIMsX", 0], ["G7rn9VqG", 0], ["ig9ZmkEh", 0], ["T5cGQRup", 0], ["HQGCinnx", 0], ["pQ9KSiwP", 0], ["1RCgmfGw", 0], ["hneSqm8K", 0], ["njlgbCxp", 0], ["ebqt30vf", 0], ["lcWcklLn", 0], ["iGXxB3nr", 0]], []

(3)(+0000003): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"gy0DKqod", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2012)", plainCitation:"(2012)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:6129, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/GG33H8V5"], itemData:{id:6129, type:"thesis", abstract:"Nowadays,the gap between the rich and poor has become a hot-button issue in Chinese society.In recent years,the widening rich-poor gap has brought about widespread perception of distributive injustice and such social mentality as resentment of the rich and officials.According to the attribution theory of perception of distributive injustice and its relevant studies,individuals\u2019 attribution tendency in the gap between the rich and poor can strongly predict their perception of distributive injustice.Therefore,understanding the attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap for for different social classes has important practical implications for administers to monitor and alleviate public perception of injustice effectively,cultivate rational and calm national mentality,and maintain social stability.However,seen from the current research situation,although attribution has been always an important research subject in the field of social cognition,there has been only a few studies on social class and attribution tendency and even less studies on social class and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap.This dissertation,based on the theoretical background of culture and attribution and focusing on social class--an important subculture variable and the social reality situation of the rich-poor gap,aimed to explore the attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap for different social classes systematically through the following 6 concrete studies.Study 1 developed the rich-poor gap attribution questionnaire and investigated the relationship between social class\uFF08including objective social class and subjective social class\uFF09and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap with a sample of 1,781 urban and rural residents.The results showed that lower subjective social class individuals in our samples were more likely to attribute the gap between the rich and poor to such external contextual factors as inequitable distribution of resources,guan-xi or personal connections,and family background.But objective social class was not stably and consistently associated with individual\u2019s attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap.To further reveal the causal relationship between subjective social class and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap,study 2,with 73 middle class adults as participants,experimentally manipulated individuals\u2019 subjective social class,to examine the effect of individuals\u2019 temporary experience of relative social class on their attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap.The results also indicated that lower subjective social class individuals tended to make more external attribution in the rich-poor gap.Further,study 3,study 4 and study 5 explored the psychological mechanism of the influence of subjective social class on attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap mainly from the angle of cognition and motivation.Study 3 examined the effect of analytic-holistic cognitive style,using the methods of eye movement and behavioral experiment and 60 typical high and low class individuals as its participants;study 4 examined the effect of self-serving motive,using the method of scene experiment and 147 middle class adults as its participants;study 5 investigated 831 urban and rural residents to revise the scale of sense of control and test the mediation effect of perceived control.The results of the above-mentioned 3 studies showed that,the reason why lower subjective social class individuals were more likely to attribute the rich-poor gap to external contextual factors was neither mainly due to the analytic-holistic cognitive style nor the self-serving motive;it was the sense of control that partially mediated the relationship between subjective social class and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap.Specifically,lower subjective social class individuals tended to feel lower personal control;as a result of this lower sense of personal control,they were more likely to explain the gap between the rich and poor in terms of external causes rather than internal causes.The effects of the analytic-holistic cognitive style and the self-serving motive were not verified well in our studies,which needed to be further tested in future research.Finally,grounded on the mediation effect of perceived control on the relationship between subjective social class and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap,study 6 adopted the method of situational simulated experiment with a sample of 93 undergraduates as participants,to further examine the moderation effect of social constraints on external attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap for lower social class individuals,which was expected to provide a reference for public management countermeasures of promoting lower social class individuals to reduce external attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap.The results showed that the moderation effect of social constraints was significant.Specifically,in the situation with less social constraints,there was a marked reduction of the tendency for lower class individuals to make more external explanations for the gap between the rich and poor,which indicated that reducing social constraints could help lower class individuals to downplay external causes of the gap between the rich and poor.To sum up,the above-mentioned 6 studies focused on the relationship between social class and attribution tendency in the rich-poor gap and solved the 3 big questions of \u201Cwhat\u201D,\u201Cwhy\u201D and \u201Chow\u201D.", genre:"\u535A\u58EB", language:"zh-CN", note:"DOI: 10.27159/d.cnki.ghzsu.2012.000005", publisher:"\u534E\u4E2D\u5E08\u8303\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u4E0D\u540C\u793E\u4F1A\u9636\u5C42\u5BF9\u8D2B\u5BCC\u5DEE\u8DDD\u7684\u5F52\u56E0\u503E\u5411\u7814\u7A76", author:[{literal:"\u674E\u9759"}], contributor:[{literal:"\u90ED\u6C38\u7389"}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2022", 5, 29]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2012"]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], (3)(+0000010): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"KzXuIQDh", properties:{formattedCitation:"(1998)", plainCitation:"(1998)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:10027, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/KZ3XIWQ6"], itemData:{id:10027, type:"article-journal", abstract:"The authors examined social class differences in 2 aspects of the sense of control (mastery and perceived constraints) in 3 national probability samples of men and women ages 25-75 years (N1 = 1,014; N2 = 1,195; N3 = 3,485). Participants with lower income had lower perceived mastery and higher perceived constraints, as well as poorer health. Results of hierarchical multiple regression analyses showed that for all income groups, higher perceived mastery and lower perceived constraints were related to better health, greater life satisfaction, and lower depressive symptoms. However, control beliefs played a moderating role; participants in the lowest income group with a high sense of control showed levels of health and well-being comparable with the higher income groups. The results provided some evidence that psychosocial variables such as sense of control may be useful in understanding social class differences in health.", 'container-title':"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology", DOI:"10/b53pht", ISSN:"0022-3514", issue:"3", journalAbbreviation:"J Pers Soc Psychol", language:"en", note:"PMID: 9523418", page:"763-773", source:"PubMed", title:"The sense of control as a moderator of social class differences in health and well-being", volume:"74", author:[{family:"Lachman", given:"M. abstract:"\u5728\u6211\u56FD\u4EBA\u53E3\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u7684\u80CC\u666F\u4E4B\u4E0B,\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u798F\u7949\u9700\u8981\u5F97\u5230\u66F4\u591A\u5173\u6CE8\u3002\u57FA\u4E8E\u6B64,\u672C\u7814\u7A76\u65E8\u5728\u8C03\u67E5\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u3001\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u4E0E\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u7684\u73B0\u72B6\u5E76\u63A2\u8BA8\u4E09\u8005\u7684\u76F8\u5173\u5173\u7CFB,\u8868\u660E\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u5728\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u548C\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u4E4B\u95F4\u5B58\u5728\u4E2D\u4ECB\u4F5C\u7528\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u9009\u53D6\u5C45\u4F4F\u5728\u5185\u8499\u53E4\u81EA\u6CBB\u533A\u67D0\u5E024\u4E2A\u793E\u533A\u7684520\u4F4D\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3A\u88AB\u8BD5,\u91C7\u7528\u300A\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u91CF\u8868\u300B\u3001\u300A\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u6E90\u91CF\u8868\u300B\u3001\u300A\u7EBD\u82AC\u5170\u7EAA\u5FF5\u5927\u5B66\u5E78\u798F\u5EA6\u91CF\u8868\u300B\u8FDB\u884C\u6D4B\u8BD5\u3002\u4F7F\u7528SPSS26.0\u7EDF\u8BA1\u8F6F\u4EF6\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u3001\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u3001\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u5728\u4EBA\u53E3\u5B66\u53D8\u91CF\u4E0A\u7684\u5DEE\u5F02\u548C\u4E09\u8005\u4E4B\u95F4\u7684\u5173\u7CFB\u8FDB\u884C\u5206\u6790;\u4F7F\u7528PROCESS\u63D2\u4EF6\u8FDB\u884C\u4E2D\u4ECB\u6548\u5E94\u5206\u6790\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u8868\u660E:(1)\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u5904\u4E8E\u4E2D\u7B49\u504F\u4E0A\u6C34\u5E73,\u5E76\u5728\u4EBA\u53E3\u5B66\u53D8\u91CF\u4E0A\u5B58\u5728\u663E\u8457\u5DEE\u5F02\u3002\u5176\u4E2D\u5065\u5EB7\u72B6\u51B5\u826F\u597D\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;60-69\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E70-90\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u6237\u7C4D\u6240\u5728\u5730\u4E3A\u57CE\u5E02\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u6709\u914D\u5076\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E\u65E0\u914D\u5076\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u62E5\u67091\u4E2A\u5B50\u5973\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E\u62E5\u67093\u4E2A\u62163\u4E2A\u4EE5\u4E0A\u5B50\u5973\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u4E0E\u8001\u4F34\u548C\u5B50\u5973\u540C\u4F4F\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u6700\u9AD8;\u6587\u5316\u6C34\u5E73\u5728\u9AD8\u4E2D\u4EE5\u4E0A\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u76F8\u5BF9\u66F4\u9AD8;\u4E2A\u4EBA\u5E73\u5747\u6708\u6536\u5165\u8D8A\u9AD8\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u8D8A\u9AD8\u3002(2)\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u5904\u4E8E\u4E2D\u7B49\u504F\u4E0A\u6C34\u5E73,\u5E76\u5728\u4EBA\u53E3\u5B66\u53D8\u91CF\u4E0A\u5B58\u5728\u663E\u8457\u5DEE\u5F02\u3002\u5176\u4E2D\u5065\u5EB7\u72B6\u51B5\u826F\u597D\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;60-69\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E80-90\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u6709\u914D\u5076\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u4E0E\u8001\u4F34\u548C\u5B50\u5973\u540C\u4F4F\u6216\u4E0E\u8001\u4F34\u540C\u4F4F\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u6587\u5316\u6C34\u5E73\u9AD8\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u9000\u4F11\u524D\u5728\u56FD\u5BB6\u673A\u5173\u3001\u4E8B\u4E1A\u5355\u4F4D\u5DE5\u4F5C\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E\u9000\u4F11\u524D\u662F\u5DE5\u4EBA\u6216\u519C\u6C11\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u4E2A\u4EBA\u5E73\u5747\u6708\u6536\u5165\u8D8A\u9AD8\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u8D8A\u9AD8\u3002(3)\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u5904\u4E8E\u4E2D\u7B49\u6C34\u5E73,\u5E76\u5728\u4EBA\u53E3\u5B66\u53D8\u91CF\u4E0A\u5B58\u5728\u663E\u8457\u5DEE\u5F02\u3002\u5176\u4E2D\u5065\u5EB7\u72B6\u51B5\u826F\u597D\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;60-69\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E70-90\u5C81\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u6237\u7C4D\u6240\u5728\u5730\u4E3A\u57CE\u5E02\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u6709\u914D\u5076\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u9AD8\u4E8E\u65E0\u914D\u5076\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u62E5\u67091\u4E2A\u5B50\u5973\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u5927\u4E8E\u62E5\u67093\u4E2A\u62163\u4E2A\u4EE5\u4E0A\u5B50\u5973\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA;\u4E0E\u8001\u4F34\u548C\u5B50\u5973\u540C\u4F4F\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u6700\u9AD8;\u6587\u5316\u6C34\u5E73\u5728\u9AD8\u4E2D\u4EE5\u4E0A\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u66F4\u9AD8;\u4E2A\u4EBA\u5E73\u5747\u6708\u6536\u5165\u8D8A\u9AD8\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u8D8A\u9AD8\u3002(4)\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u3001\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u6709\u663E\u8457\u9884\u6D4B\u4F5C\u7528,\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u53EF\u4EE5\u901A\u8FC7\u751F\u547D\u610F\u4E49\u611F\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u4E3B\u89C2\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u4EA7\u751F\u5F71\u54CD\u3002", abstract:"\u7814\u7A76\u80CC\u666F\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u5DF2\u7ECF\u6210\u4E3A\u793E\u4F1A\u5171\u540C\u5173\u6CE8\u7684\u95EE\u9898\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u8BA4\u4E3A,\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u4E0E\u4EBA\u683C\u56E0\u7D20\u6709\u7740\u5BC6\u5207\u7684\u5173\u7CFB,\u800C\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4F5C\u4E3A\u4E2A\u4F53\u76F8\u5BF9\u7A33\u5B9A\u7684\u4EBA\u683C\u8BA4\u77E5\u56E0\u7D20\u662F\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u8EAB\u5FC3\u5065\u5EB7\u7684\u91CD\u8981\u4FDD\u62A4\u6027\u56E0\u7D20\u3002\u4E0E\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u7684\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u4FA7\u91CD\u4E8E\u53CD\u6620\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5BF9\u81EA\u6211\u5065\u5EB7\u63A7\u5236\u7684\u4FE1\u5FF5,\u5B83\u53EF\u4EE5\u5F71\u54CD\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u81EA\u6211\u62A4\u7406\u7684\u4FE1\u5FC3\u53CA\u80FD\u529B,\u4ECE\u800C\u5F71\u54CD\u5176\u8EAB\u5FC3\u72B6\u51B5\u548C\u751F\u6D3B\u8D28\u91CF\u3002\u56E0\u6B64\u6B63\u786E\u8BC4\u4F30\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F,\u5206\u6790\u76F8\u5173\u5F71\u54CD\u56E0\u7D20,\u5BF9\u5E2E\u52A9\u3001\u6307\u5BFC\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u8DF5\u884C\u5065\u5EB7\u8001\u9F84\u5316\u5177\u6709\u91CD\u8981\u610F\u4E49\u3002\u76EE\u524D\u56FD\u5185\u5916\u5BF9\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u7814\u7A76\u591A\u96C6\u4E2D\u4E8E\u5BF9\u4E00\u822C\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u6216\u7279\u5B9A\u9886\u57DF\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u8FDB\u884C\u8BC4\u4F30,\u800C\u5BF9\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u8BC4\u4F30\u76F8\u5BF9\u8F83\u5C11,\u4E14\u5BF9\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u8BC4\u4F30\u5DE5\u5177\u7684\u7814\u7A76\u591A\u91C7\u7528\u4E00\u822C\u4EBA\u7FA4\u7684\u666E\u9002\u6027\u95EE\u5377,\u5C11\u89C1\u4E13\u7528\u4E8E\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u7684\u8BC4\u4F30\u5DE5\u5177\u3002Claassens,L.\u535A\u58EB\u7814\u5236\u7684\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F\u95EE\u5377,\u4E13\u7528\u4E8E\u8BC4\u4F30\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u7684\u5065\u5EB7\u76F8\u5173\u63A7\u5236\u611F,\u4E14\u5177\u6709\u826 (3)(+0000002): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"mzcpaLZT", properties:{formattedCitation:"(Kidd et al., 2009)", plainCitation:"(Kidd et al., 2009)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:10086, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/VLU9RJ3G"], itemData:{id:10086, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Aim: \nThis paper reports the qualitative findings from a mixed methods study which explored patients' understandings of perceived control in relation to their self care during chemotherapy for colorectal cancer.\n\nBackground:\nA greater degree of patient involvement in self care is increasingly being encouraged; however, little is known about how factors such as perceived control influence patients' active involvement in self care.\n\nDesign:\nQualitative, longitudinal study.\n\nMethods:\nSemi structured interviews were conducted with 11 patients before and after six months of chemotherapy treatment for colorectal cancer in a Scottish cancer centre between March 2005-June 2006. The interviews, conducted as part of a larger study, explored patients' understandings of their perceived control over managing treatment-related side effects and how this influenced their attitudes toward, and role preferences in, self care.\n\nResults:\nPatients fell into one of two groups: 'high' or 'low' perceived controllers. High-perceived controllers were more likely to view their active involvement in self care positively, as being necessary in managing treatment-related effects and were less likely to rely on nurses to take overall responsibility for the management of treatment-related side effects. Low-perceived controllers were less likely to believe in the importance or necessity of their active involvement in self care and more likely to perceive nurses as being the ones responsible for the management of treatment-related side effects.\n\nConclusions:\nPerceived control during treatment for cancer influences patients' perceptions toward, and role preferences in, self care.\n\nRelevance to clinical practice:\nClinical interventions designed to enhance involvement in self care would benefit from focussing on enhancing patients' perceived control and understanding their role preferences in self care. Patients with different understandings of perceived control may require different help and support to encourage their involvement in self care.", 'call-number':"2", 'container-title':"Journal of (3)(+0000039): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"cIyT6kj5", properties:{formattedCitation:"(Infurna et al., 2011)", plainCitation:"(Infurna et al., 2011)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:6213, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/A4RJN4AZ"], itemData:{id:6213, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Perceived control plays an important role in shaping development throughout adulthood and old age. Using data from the adult lifespan sample of the national German Socio-Economic Panel (SOEP; N > 10,000, covering 25 years of measurement), we explored long-term antecedents, correlates, and outcomes of perceived control and examined if associations differ with age. Targeting correlates and antecedents of control, findings indicated that higher concurrent levels of social participation, life satisfaction, and self-rated health as well as more positive changes in social participation over the preceding 11 years were each predictive of between-person differences in perceived control. Targeting health outcomes of control, survival analyses revealed that perceived control predicted 14-year hazard ratio for disability (n = 996 became disabled) and mortality (n = 1,382 died). The effect for mortality, but not for disability, was independent of sociodemographic and psychosocial factors. Overall, we found very limited support for age-differential associations.
