(3)(+0000004): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"IQdA1MjD", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2017)", plainCitation:"(2017)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:4931, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/6S9EUIF8"], itemData:{id:4931, type:"thesis", abstract:"With the improvement of technology environment in China,the health of the elderly continues to improve,the elderly on the diversification of life after retirement,the level of demand has increased.On the one hand,in the elderly way of enriching the elderly,the spiritual level of demand makes some of the elderly hope that after retirement,through re-employment to achieve self-worth,is also in different stages of retirement,how to enrich the post-retirement life planning.Retired people have rich social experience,the job skills and expertise in the work of the advantages of young workers do not have,if we can make some of the conditions of the elderly through re-employment,re-enter the social production which can Give full play to the advantages of retirement experience,rich in the retirement life of the elderly at the same time,contribute to social development and more contributions.Retirement re-employment is not only an important direction for the development of the elderly in China,but also an effective channel to cope with the disappearance of China\u2019s hole dividend and the shortage of social labor resources.Re-employment of the elderly not only for social and business development to provide more help,but also the development of China\u2019s human resources component.Elderly people not only have a sense of old age,old age,but also a sense of worthiness,participate in social life at the same time enhance the understanding of self-worth,at the same time,its labor income can also help retirees and their families to improve Quality of life,and promote social harmony and development.However,The study found that in recent years,Linyi City,Shandong Province,the proportion of retired elderly employment has improved,and the proportion of male elderly employment to be significantly higher than the proportion of female elderly employment.The retired elderly are engaged in a wide range of occupations,mainly engaged in the production type of work,followed by the choice is engaged in business,service work,the third is as equipment operators,there are very few elderly people choose other employment channels.Re-employment channels for the retired persons there are six kinds,namely,through the introduction of friends and family,to participate in social recruitment,registration to find an intermediary position,job advertisements,self-employment or through other channels re-employment.The existing problems of reemployment of retirees in Linyi City mainly include social support insufficiency,unstable labor participation situation,backwardness of the old people,low utilization rate of the old human resources,low quality of the old manpower resources,comprehensive application of AHP and data statistic method.,The factors influencing the retirement and re-employment of the elderly were analyzed synthetically.The correlation values of physiological needs,safety requirements,attribution and love,respect for needs and self-actualization were 0.755,0.632,0.572,0.726,0.663,The paper puts forward the countermeasures and suggestions to improve the reemployment of the retirees in China,including the basic principles of employment for the aged,and the concept of retired reemployment must fully reflect the strategic goal orientation of the society,Enhance the subjective feelings of the elderly after re-employment and the realization of self-worth,improve the elderly re-employment mechanism,improve the education system for the elderly,the establishment of retired workers re-employment policy security system,the establishment of retired staff re-employment management services and a series of Measures.To the community to accept the re-employment of retirees,not only from the national policy to give retired employees re-employment development of the cause to protect,give the elderly policy support,but also from the whole society to give the elderly re-employment to support,only Social and retired people to understand each other,mutual recognition,in order to promote the development of retired re-employment,enhance their social status.With the development of society,the goal that people pursue is no longer \"live\" but to live better,more quality,the elderly is no exception,promote the reemployment of retirees to promote social and economic stability,high speed,sustainable development.", genre:"\u7855\u58EB", language:"zh-CN", publisher:"\u5357\u4EAC\u822A\u7A7A\u822A\u5929\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u4E2D\u56FD\u9000\u4F11\u4EBA\u5458\u518D\u5C31\u4E1A\u95EE\u9898\u7814\u7A76", (3)(+0000015): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"EnWdbZbI", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2019)", plainCitation:"(2019)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:1733, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/K4JT66HK"], itemData:{id:1733, type:"thesis", abstract:"Objectives1.To explore the effect of self-perception aging on the psychological well-being of the elderly in community.2.To test the mediating effect of social participation on self-perceived aging and psychological well-being.MethodsFrom September 2017 to August 2018,850 elderly people from six typical communities in Tangshan City were conveniently selected as subjects.Using the Aging Perceptions Questionnaire\uFF08APQ\uFF09,Social Participation Scale and Psychological Well-being Questionnaire in Multiple Happiness Questionnaire\uFF08MHQ\uFF09was used to investigate the self-perceived aging degree,social participation degree and psychological well-being level of the elderly in the community.Meanwhile,self-designed general situation questionnaire,Family APGAR index and ability assessment scale of the elderly were used to investigate the influencing factors of psychological well-being.The data were analyzed by SPSS17.0statistical software.The influencing factors of psychological well-being of the elderly were analyzed by t-test,one-way ANOVA and multiple linear regression.Pearson correlation analysis was used to analyze the correlation among self-perceived aging,social participation and psychological well-being.We analyzed the mediating effect between self-perceived aging and psychological well-being by using Wen Zhonglin\u2019s mediating effect test procedure.Results1.The total score of psychological well-being of the elderly in the community was\uFF08156.04\xB125.93\uFF09.The level of psychological well-being was in the upper middle level.2.The results of single factor analysis showed that there were significant differences in the level of psychological well-being among age,marital status,educational level,monthly income,family structure,change of perception function,community function,family care,positive perception aging and negative perception aging\uFF08all P<0.05\uFF09.There was no significant difference in the level of psychological well-being between different genders\uFF08P>0.05\uFF09.3.Multivariate linear stratified regression analysis showed that monthly income,changes in perceived function,community function,family care,positive self-perception aging and negative self-perception aging affected the elderly\u2019s psychological well-being.In the first layer,the adjusted R2 is 0.418 when the positive perception aging is not included in the regression equation,and when the positive perception aging is included in the second layer,the adjusted R2 is 0.482.Positive perception aging can explain 6.4%of the total variation of the elderly\u2019s psychological well-being.In the second layer,when the negative perception aging is not included in the regression equation,the adjusted R2 is0.482,when the negative perception aging is included in the third layer,the adjusted R2 is0.552,and the negative perception aging can explain 7%of the total variation of the elderly\u2019s psychological well-being.4 Pearson correlation analysis showed that social participation was positively correlated with psychological well-being and positive perception aging\uFF08r=0.593,0.303,P<0.05\uFF09,negatively correlated with negative perception aging\uFF08r=-0.305,P<0.05\uFF09,positively correlated with positive perception aging\uFF08r=0.463,P<0.05\uFF09,negatively correlated with negative perception aging\uFF08r=-0.518,P<0.05\uFF09.5.The results of mediating effect showed that social participation had a partial mediating effect between positive perception aging and psychological well-being\uFF08P<0.05\uFF09,the mediating effect was 0.151,the direct effect was0.312 and the total effect is 0.463.The contribution rate of mediating effect to the total effect was Ettect M=0.303*0.499/0.463=32.6%.Social participation had a partial mediating effect between negative perception aging and psychological well-being\uFF08P<0.05\uFF09.The mediation effect was-0.305*0.480=-0.146,the direct effect was-0.371 and the total effect was-0.518.The contribution rate of mediation effect to the total effect was Ettect M=-0.305*0.480/-0.518=28.2%.Conclusions1.The psychological well-being of the elderly in the community is on the upper middle level.2.Monthly income,change of perception function,community function,family care,positive self-perception aging and negative self-perception aging are the influencing factors of psychological well-being of the elderly in the community.Improving the positive self-perception aging level of the elderly and reducing the negative self-perception aging level of the elderly will help to improve their psychological well-being level.3.Social participation plays a mediating role between positive perception of aging,negative perception of aging and psychological well-being of the elderly.Improving the level of positive self-perception of aging of the elderly and reducing the level of negative self-perception of aging of the elderly can improve their level of social participation,and then improve their psychological well-being.Figure 1;Table 9;Reference 106", genre:"\u7855\u58EB", language:"zh-CN", publisher:"\u534E\u5317\u7406\u5DE5\u5927\u5B66", source:"CNKI", title:"\u81EA\u6211\u611F\u77E5\u8001\u5316\u5BF9\u793E\u533A\u8001\u5E74\u4EBA\u5FC3\u7406\u5E78\u798F\u611F\u7684\u5F71\u54CD\uFF1A\u793E\u4F1A\u53C2\u4E0E\u7684\u4E2D\u4ECB\u4F5C\u7528", URL:"https://oversea.cnki.net/KCMS/detail/detail.aspx?dbcode=CMFD&dbname=CMFD202001&filename=1019669751.nh&uniplatform=OVERSEAS_EN&v=Q5DV7XQ4OUPX-XwADMKF4gokzlEuOSeLvIQ_B7JvWQv_UkxHlIwZFGl1rTgrwUhE", author:[{literal:"\u767D\u4E9A\u4E3D"}], contributor:[{literal:"\u8D75\u96C5\u5B81"}], accessed:{'date-parts':[["2022", 4, 2]]}, issued:{'date-parts':[["2019"]]}}, label:"page", (3)(+0000002): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"UBBJ05mS", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2022)", plainCitation:"(2022)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:8220, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/5UY3JUA2"], itemData:{id:8220, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Objective\nWe aimed to examine the association between social participation and depressive symptoms among Chinese older people aged 65 years or above to supplement limited studies in China on this topic.\n\nMethods\nThis community-based longitudinal prospective cohort study used the data from the Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey (CLHLS, baseline in 2014 and a follow-up in 2018). Depressive symptoms were assessed using the 10-item Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale. Social participation was assessed using a composite index by considering the frequency for the two types of social activity: organized social activities and informal activities. Pearson's \u03C72 test was used to correlate the characteristics of participants with social participation or depressive symptoms. Log-binomial regression models were used to assess the association between social participation and the risk of depressive symptoms.\n\nResults\nThe incidence of depressive symptoms was 28.8% among 2,200 participants in 2018 after a 4-year follow-up. Participants with no social participation (32.6%), organized social activities (30.6%), or informal social activities (31.2%) were more likely to have depressive symptoms. After the adjustment of demographic factors, socioeconomic status, lifestyle habits, and health status, in comparison with older people who often engaged in social participation, organized social activities, and informal social activities, the risk of depressive symptoms was 45% [adjusted risk ratio (aRR): 1.45, 95% CI: 1.16\u20131.82], 42% (aRR: 1.45, 95% CI: 1.02\u20132.00), and 29% (aRR: 1.29, 95% CI: 1.02\u20131.99) higher among older people with no social participation and who never engaged in organized social activities and informal social activities, respectively.\n\nConclusions\nThis study showed that the lack of social participation, including organized social activities and informal social activities, was associated with a higher risk of depressive symptoms after 4 years among older adults in China. Our findings shed lights into the feasibility of promoting social participation to reduce the risk of depressive symptoms and promote longevity and healthy aging among older adults.", note:"PMID: 35223728\nPMCID: PMC8863664", page:"781771", source:"3", title:"Less Social Participation Is Associated With a Higher Risk of Depressive Symptoms Among Chinese Older Adults: A (3)(+0000005): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"vZPlReKU", properties:{formattedCitation:"(R. Curtis et al., 2016)", plainCitation:"(R. Curtis et al., 2016)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:"SOVY2tYh/mlwarkJW", uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/58REE5KL"], itemData:{id:8335, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Objectives:\nPerceived control may promote social activity in older adults because individuals with greater perceived control have greater confidence in their ability to achieve outcomes and are more likely to choose difficult activities, show persistence, and employ strategies to overcome challenges. Cross-sectional research has linked perceived control with social activity in life span and older adult samples but provides little insight into the direction of influence. We examined reciprocal associations between perceived control and social activity in order to establish temporal sequencing, which is one prerequisite for determining potential causation.\n\nMethod:\nParticipants were 14,126 midlife and older adults from the German Ageing Survey. Using cross-lagged autoregressive modeling with age as the time metric (40\u201387 years), we examined reciprocal 3-year lagged associations between perceived control and social activity, while controlling for concurrent associations.\n\nResults:\nPerceived control significantly predicted social activity 3 years later. Reciprocally, social activity significantly predicted perceived control 3 years later. The influence of perceived control on social activity was greater than the influence of social activity on perceived control.\n\nDiscussion:\nThe finding that perceived control significantly predicts future social activity has potential implications for developing interventions aimed at promoting social activity in midlife and older adults.", archive_location:"12 citation(s)", 'container-title':"The Journals of Gerontology Series B: Psychological Sciences and Social Sciences", DOI:"10.1093/geronb/gbw070", journalAbbreviation:"The Journals of Gerontology Series B: Psychological Sciences and Social Sciences", page:"807-815", source:"ResearchGate", title:"Perceived Control and Social Activity in Midlife and Older Age: A Reciprocal Association? (3)(+0000009): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"V2CzrYIN", properties:{formattedCitation:"(1980)", plainCitation:"(1980)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:10146, uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/W6RTCNNN"], itemData:{id:10146, type:"article-journal", abstract:"A career is defined as the combination and sequence of roles played by a person during the course of a lifetime. These roles include those of child, pupil or student, leisurite, citizen, worker, spouse, homemaker, parent, and pensioner, positions with associated expectations that are occupied at some time by most people, and other less common roles such as those of criminal, reformer, and lover. A Life-Career Rainbow is presented as a means of helping conceptualize multidimensional careers, the temporal involvement in, and the emotional commitment to, each role. Self-actualization in various roles, role conflicts, and the determinants of role selection and of role performance are discussed. The use of the Rainbow in career education and in counseling is briefly considered.", 'container-title':"Journal of Vocational Behavior", DOI:"10/fvk7c8", journalAbbreviation:"Journal of Vocational uris:["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/53NLYZH3"], itemData:{id:10144, type:"thesis", abstract:"\u6211\u56FD\u6B63\u5904\u4E8E\u7531\u5236\u9020\u5927\u56FD\u5411\u5236\u9020\u5F3A\u56FD\u7684\u8F6C\u578B\u671F,\u9700\u8981\u5927\u91CF\u6280\u672F\u6280\u80FD\u578B\u4EBA\u624D\u4E0E\u4E4B\u914D\u5957,\u800C\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u4F5C\u4E3A\u793E\u4F1A\u52B3\u52A8\u529B\u7684\u91CD\u8981\u7EC4\u6210\u90E8\u5206,\u5176\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u7684\u53D1\u5C55\u4E0E\u793E\u4F1A\u7684\u53D1\u5C55\u662F\u606F\u606F\u76F8\u5173\u7684\u3002\u6B64\u5916,2018\u5E74\u6559\u80B2\u90E8\u5370\u53D1\u300A\u4E2D\u7B49\u804C\u4E1A\u5B66\u6821\u804C\u4E1A\u6307\u5BFC\u5DE5\u4F5C\u89C4\u5B9A\u300B,\u660E\u786E\u6307\u51FA\u8981\u57F9\u517B\u5B66\u751F\u89C4\u5212\u7BA1\u7406\u5B66\u4E1A\u3001\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u7684\u610F\u8BC6\u548C\u80FD\u529B,\u4F46\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u9AD8\u79BB\u804C\u7387\u3001\u9AD8\u8F6C\u4E1A\u7387\u7684\u73B0\u5B9E\u60C5\u51B5\u4E5F\u53CD\u6620\u51FA\u5B66\u751F\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u5B58\u5728\u8BF8\u591A\u95EE\u9898\u6709\u5F85\u89E3\u51B3\u3002\u8212\u4F2F\u4F5C\u4E3A\u4E16\u754C\u804C\u4E1A\u89C4\u5212\u4E0E\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u9886\u57DF\u6743\u5A01\u7684\u4EE3\u8868\u4EBA\u7269,\u4ED6\u6253\u5F00\u4E86\u4E00\u4E2A\u5168\u65B0\u7684\u89C6\u89D2,\u63A8\u52A8\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u9759\u6001\u7684\u4EBA\u804C\u5339\u914D\u5230\u52A8\u6001\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6301\u7EED\u53D1\u5C55,\u5176\u6210\u719F\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u5DF2\u5F97\u5230\u591A\u4E2A\u56FD\u5BB6\u7684\u8FD0\u7528\u548C\u56FD\u5185\u4E13\u5BB6\u5B66\u8005\u7684\u80AF\u5B9A,\u5BF9\u6211\u56FD\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u6709\u7740\u91CD\u8981\u7684\u501F\u9274\u4EF7\u503C\u548C\u610F\u4E49\u3002\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u4EE5\u81EA\u6211\u6982\u5FF5\u4F5C\u4E3A\u57FA\u7840\u6838\u5FC3,\u4EE5\u751F\u6DAF\u6210\u719F\u5EA6\u4F5C\u4E3A\u6D4B\u91CF,\u5E76\u63D0\u51FA\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u62F1\u95E8\u6A21\u5F0F\u3001\u4E94\u9636\u6BB5\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u3001\u5FAA\u73AF\u5F0F\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u3001\u751F\u6DAF\u5F69\u8679\u56FE\u7B49\u89C2\u70B9\u3002\u8BE5\u7406\u8BBA\u4E0E\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u7684\u672C\u8D28\u662F\u5951\u5408\u76F8\u878D\u7684,\u90FD\u5728\u7A81\u51FA\u5F3A\u8C03\u4E86\u4E2A\u4F53\u7684\u4E3B\u4F53\u5730\u4F4D\u3002\u7ED3\u5408\u6211\u56FD\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u7684\u73B0\u72B6,\u8212\u4F2F\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u53EF\u4F7F\u6211\u56FD\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u66F4\u5177\u79D1\u5B66\u6027\u548C\u6709\u6548\u6027,\u63D0\u4F9B\u65B0\u7684\u6307\u5BFC\u65B9\u5411\u548C\u7406\u5FF5\u3002\u672C\u7814\u7A76\u4EE5\u8212\u4F2F\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u4E3A\u57FA\u70B9,\u9996\u5148,\u4ECE\u5B66\u751F\u7684\u89C6\u89D2\u51FA\u53D1\u7814\u7A76\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u7684\u73B0\u72B6,\u5E76\u5206\u6790\u548C\u68B3\u7406\u5B9E\u8DF5\u4E2D\u5B58\u5728\u7684\u95EE\u9898\u3002\u4E4B\u540E\u501F\u9274\u8212\u4F2F\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u6709\u4EF7\u503C\u7684\u6210\u5206,\u4EE5\u5B66\u751F\u3001\u5B66\u6821\u3001\u793E\u4F1A\u4E09\u5927\u4E3B\u7EBF\u8FDB\u884C\u539F\u56E0\u63A2\u7A76,\u5E76\u8BD5\u56FE\u9488\u5BF9\u5B66\u751F\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u5B58\u5728\u7684\u95EE\u9898\u53CA\u80CC\u540E\u7684\u539F\u56E0,\u63D0\u51FA\u76F8\u5E94\u7684\u6539\u8FDB\u5BF9\u7B56\u3002\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u5E94\u63D0\u9AD8\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u8BA4\u77E5,\u6B63\u786E\u8BA4\u8BC6\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u3001\u52A0\u5F3A\u6784\u5EFA\u81EA\u6211\u6982\u5FF5\u3001\u5B66\u4F1A\u8F6C\u5316\u89D2\u8272\u626E\u6F14\u3001\u5168\u9762\u63D0\u9AD8\u751F\u6DAF\u6210\u719F\u5EA6\u3001\u660E\u786E\u4E2A\u4EBA\u804C\u4E1A\u76EE\u6807;\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u6821\u5E94\u52A0\u5F3A\u5F15\u5BFC,\u6811\u7ACB\u52A8\u6001\u53D1\u5C55\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u7406\u5FF5\u3001\u5065\u5168\u4E13\u4E1A\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u7EC4\u7EC7\u3001\u5F00\u62D3\u591A\u6837\u5316\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u6307\u5BFC\u6E20\u9053\u3001\u5206\u9636\u6BB5\u6307\u5BFC\u5B66\u751F\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u4EE5\u53CA\u63D0\u9AD8\u6559\u5E08\u4E13\u4E1A\u5316\u6307\u5BFC\u6C34\u5E73;\u793E\u4F1A\u5404\u754C\u5E94\u5BFB\u6C42\u5404\u65B9\u7684\u5408\u4F5C\u652F\u6301,\u653F\u5E9C\u63D0\u4F9B\u653F\u7B56\u4FDD\u969C\u3001\u4F01\u4E1A\u4EA7\u6559\u878D\u5408\u5BFB\u6C42\u5B9E\u8DF5\u673A\u4F1A\u4EE5\u53CA\u5BB6\u5EAD\u6559\u80B2\u6709\u6548\u5F15\u5BFC,\u529B\u6C42\u53EF\u4EE5\u6539\u5584\u4E2D\u804C\u5B66\u751F\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u751F\u6DAF\u89C4\u5212\u73B0\u72B6,\u5B9E\u73B0\u4E2A\u4F53\u7684\u826F\u597D\u53D1\u5C55\u3002", abstract:"\u5982\u4F55\u6784\u5EFA\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u8BFE\u7A0B\u4F53\u7CFB\u3001\u63D0\u5347\u5E7F\u5927\u4E2D\u5C0F\u5B66\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u6C34\u5E73,\u8FD9\u662F\u5F53\u524D\u6DF1\u5316\u57FA\u7840\u6559\u80B2\u8BFE\u7A0B\u6539\u9769\u3001\u7A33\u6B65\u63A8\u8FDB\u201C\u65B0\u9AD8\u8003\u201D\u4EFB\u52A1\u7684\u91CD\u8981\u6293\u624B,\u4E5F\u662F\u52A0\u5F3A\u5B66\u6821\u4E0E\u793E\u4F1A\u8054\u7CFB\u3001\u843D\u5B9E\u7ACB\u5FB7\u6811\u4EBA\u6839\u672C\u4EFB\u52A1\u7684\u5185\u5728\u8981\u6C42\u3002\u7F8E\u56FD\u4F5C\u4E3A\u8F83\u65E9\u5F00\u5C55\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u5B9E\u8DF5\u548C\u7406\u8BBA\u7814\u7A76\u7684\u56FD\u5BB6,\u5728\u8BE5\u9886\u57DF\u79EF\u7D2F\u4E86\u4E30\u5BCC\u7684\u7ECF\u9A8C\u3002\u7136\u800C\u5F53\u524D\u56FD\u5185\u5916\u5173\u4E8E\u7F8E\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7814\u7A76\u591A\u5C5E\u4E8E\u4E2A\u522B\u4EBA\u7269\u3001\u6D41\u6D3E\u7684\u788E\u7247\u5316\u7814\u7A76,\u7F3A\u4E4F\u57FA\u4E8E\u8303\u5F0F\u7684\u7CFB\u7EDF\u68B3\u7406\u548C\u901A\u89C2\u628A\u63E1\u3002\u6279\u5224\u5438\u6536\u7F8E\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u7814\u7A76\u76F8\u5173\u6210\u679C,\u5BF9\u5B66\u754C\u628A\u63E1\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u5B66\u672F\u8109\u7EDC\u3001\u6784\u5EFA\u9002\u5207\u672C\u571F\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u6846\u67B6\u6709\u501F\u9274\u610F\u4E49\u3002\u8D2F\u7A7F\u672C\u7814\u7A76\u7684\u6838\u5FC3\u95EE\u9898:\u5728\u201C\u6548\u7387\u201D\u4E0E\u201C\u6C11\u4E3B\u201D\u3001\u201C\u79D1\u5B66\u4E3B\u4E49\u201D\u4E0E\u201C\u4EBA\u672C\u4E3B\u4E49\u201D\u7684\u8BDD\u8BED\u7ADE\u6597\u4E2D,\u7F8E\u56FD\u5B66\u754C\u5206\u5316\u51FA\u54EA\u4E9B\u6709\u5F71\u54CD\u7684\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F?\u56F4\u7ED5\u8FD9\u4E00\u6838\u5FC3\u95EE\u9898\u8FDB\u4E00\u6B65\u8FFD\u95EE:\u54EA\u4E9B\u5173\u952E\u56E0\u7D20\u5F71\u54CD\u4E86\u8FD9\u4E9B\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u7684\u5F62\u6210\u548C\u53D1\u5C55?\u8FD9\u4E9B\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u4E4B\u95F4\u6709\u54EA\u4E9B\u4E0D\u540C\u7684\u5B66\u672F\u4E3B\u5F20?\u8FD9\u4E9B\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u7684\u80CC\u540E\u6E17\u900F\u600E\u6837\u7684\u4EF7\u503C\u53D6\u5411?\u8FD9\u4E9B\u4E0D\u540C\u7684\u4EF7\u503C\u53D6\u5411\u662F\u5982\u4F55\u6839\u690D\u5728\u8BDD\u8BED\u6743\u529B\u7ED3\u6784\u5F53\u4E2D\u7684?\u5BF9\u6211\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u4E0E\u5B9E\u8DF5\u7814\u7A76\u6709\u54EA\u4E9B\u91CD\u8981\u7684\u542F\u793A?\u8FD9\u4E9B\u95EE\u9898\u6784\u6210\u4E86\u672C\u7814\u7A76\u7684\u5185\u5728\u903B\u8F91\u7EBF\u7D22\u3002\u8BBA\u6587\u9996\u5148\u8BA8\u8BBA\u4E86\u793E\u4F1A\u8F6C\u578B\u4E0E\u7F8E\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7684\u53D1\u5C55,\u5206\u522B\u4ECE\u7F8E\u56FD\u65E9\u671F\u5DE5\u4E1A\u793E\u4F1A\u3001\u665A\u671F\u5DE5\u4E1A\u793E\u4F1A\u548C\u4FE1\u606F\u5316\u793E\u4F1A\u8003\u5BDF\u5404\u4E2A\u5386\u53F2\u65F6\u671F\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u7684\u53D1\u5C55\u5F62\u6001\u3002\u7814\u7A76\u53D1\u73B0,\u675C\u5A01\u4ECE\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u915D\u917F\u65F6\u671F\u5F00\u59CB\u5C31\u4EE5\u5021\u5BFC\u201C\u666E\u804C\u878D\u5408\u201D\u3001\u201C\u901A\u8FC7\u804C\u4E1A\u7684\u6559\u80B2\u201D\u7684\u65B9\u5F0F\u8FDB\u5165\u8FD9\u4E2A\u9886\u57DF\u5E76\u6210\u4E3A\u8FD9\u9886\u57DF\u7684\u91CD\u8981\u4EBA\u7269\u3002\u6700\u521D\u675C\u5A01\u63A8\u5D07\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u7406\u60F3\u5E76\u4E0D\u88AB\u91CD\u89C6,\u4F46\u572820\u4E16\u7EAA\u665A\u671F\u5174\u8D77\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u8FD0\u52A8\u4E2D\u8D62\u5F97\u4E86\u5E7F\u6CDB\u7684\u8BA4\u53EF\u548C\u652F\u6301\u3002\u5728\u201C\u8FD4\u56DE\u675C\u5A01\u201D\u7684\u53E3\u53F7\u4E2D,\u675C\u5A01\u518D\u6B21\u6210\u4E3A\u7F8E\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7814\u7A76\u9886\u57DF\u7684\u5173\u952E\u4EBA\u7269\u3002\u8BBA\u6587\u63A5\u7740\u805A\u7126\u7F8E\u56FD\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u53D1\u5C55\u5386\u7A0B\u4E2D\u7684\u4E0D\u540C\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u5185\u90E8\u7684\u5171\u540C\u7EB2\u9886\u4EE5\u53CA\u5B83\u4EEC\u4E4B\u95F4\u7684\u8BDD\u8BED\u51B2\u7A81,\u5C24\u5176\u91CD\u89C6\u4E0D\u540C\u8BDD\u8BED\u4E4B\u95F4\u7684\u4EF7\u503C\u53D6\u5411\u4E0E\u8BDD\u8BED\u6743\u529B\u4E4B\u4E89\u3002\u5177\u4F53\u800C\u8A00,\u5373\u4E09\u4E2A\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u4E4B\u4E89:\u4E00\u662F\u4EE5\u970D\u5170\u5FB7\u6A21\u5F0F\u4E3A\u4EE3\u8868\u7684\u804C\u4E1A\u9009\u62E9\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F;\u4E8C\u662F\u4EE5\u8212\u4F2F\u6A21\u5F0F\u4E3A\u4EE3\u8868\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u53D1\u5C55\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F;\u4E09\u662F\u4EE5\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u8FD0\u52A8\u4E3A\u4EE3\u8868\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6559\u80B2\u7406\u8BBA\u8303\u5F0F\u3002\u4E09\u8005\u4E4B\u95F4,\u524D\u4E24\u8005\u53EF\u7EDF\u79F0\u4E3A\u751F\u6DAF\u54A8\u8BE2\u8303\u5F0F\u3002\u901A\u8FC7\u5206\u6790\u4E09\u79CD\u8303\u5F0F\u5185\u5728\u53CA\u4E4B\u95F4\u7684\u4E89\u6597\u5386\u7A0B,\u53D1\u6398\u6F5C\u85CF\u5728\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u80CC\u540E\u7684\u53D1\u5C55\u903B\u8F91,\u8FDB\u800C\u4E3A\u6279\u5224\u5438\u6536\u7F8E\u56FD\u76F8\u5173\u7814\u7A76\u6210\u679C\u5E76\u7ED3\u5408\u672C\u571F\u5B9E\u9645\u6784\u5EFA\u9002\u5207\u672C\u571F\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u6846\u67B6\u63D0\u4F9B\u53C2\u7167\u3002\u672C\u7814\u7A76\u53D1\u73B0,\u4E0D\u540C\u7684\u751F\u6DAF\u6307\u5BFC\u7406\u8BBA\u9690\u542B\u4E86\u7814\u7A76\u8005\u4E0D\u540C\u7684\u4EF7\u503C\u53D6\u5411,\u4E3B\u8981\u663E\u793A\u4E3A\u6548\u7387\u4E3B\u4E49\u4E0E\u6C11\u4E3B\u4E3B\u4E49\u4E4B\u4E89\u53CA\u5176\u884D\u751F\u51FA\u7684\u79D1\u5B66\u4E3B\u4E49\u4E0E\u4EBA\u672C\u4E3B\u4E49\u4E4B\u4E89\u3002\u4EF7\u503C\u53D6\u5411\u7684\u5DEE\u5F02\u5BFC\u81F4\u4E86\u7814\u7A76\u8005\u5BF9\u4EBA\u4E0E\u804C\u4E1A\u5173\u7CFB\u7684\u4E0D\u540C\u7406\u89E3,\u6548\u7387\u4E3B\u4E49\u548C\u79D1\u5B66\u4E3B\u4E49\u5728\u4EBA\u804C\u5173\u7CFB\u95EE\u9898\u4E0A\u5F80\u5F80\u5173\u6CE8\u4EE5\u804C\u4E1A\u4E3A\u4E2D\u5FC3\u7684\u4EBA\u804C\u5339\u914D\u3002\u6C11\u4E3B\u4E3B\u4E49\u548C\u4EBA\u672C\u4E3B\u4E49\u5728\u4EBA\u804C\u5173\u7CFB\u95EE\u9898\u4E0A\u5F80\u5F80\u91CD\u89C6\u201C\u5F53\u4E8B. ["ci8d5wHB", 0], ["xzDlt4TO", 0], ["6TreJ46f", 0], ["wTSqhE1a", 0]], []

(3)(+0000133): Integration: style.processCitationCluster(({citationID:"sxl6Jexz", properties:{formattedCitation:"(2022)", plainCitation:"(2022)", noteIndex:0}, citationItems:[{id:9394, uris:["http://zotero.org/groups/4709411/items/UMFRZCMB"], itemData:{id:9394, type:"article-journal", abstract:"Critics of positive psychology have questioned the validity of positive psychological assessment measures (PPAMs), which negatively affects the credibility and public perception of the discipline. Psychometric evaluations of PPAMs have shown that various instruments produce inconsistent factor structures between groups/contexts/times frames, that their predictive validity is questionable, and that popular PPAMs are culturally biased. Further, it would seem positive psychological researchers prioritize date-model-\uFB01t over measurement quality. To address these analytical challenges, more innovative and robust approaches toward the validation and evaluation of PPAMs are required to enhance the discipline\u2019s credibility and to advance positive psychological science. Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling (ESEM) has recently emerged as a promising alternative to overcome some of these challenges by incorporating the best elements from exploratory- and con\uFB01rmatory factor analyses. ESEM is still a relatively novel approach, and estimating these models in statistical software packages can be complex and tedious. Therefore, the purpose of this paper is to provide novice researchers with a practical tutorial on how to estimate ESEM with a convenient online tool for Mplus. Speci\uFB01cally, we aim to demonstrate the use of ESEM through an illustrative example by using a popular positive psychological instrument: the Mental Health Continuum-SF. By using the MHC-SF as an example, we aim to provide (a) a brief overview of ESEM (and different ESEM models/approaches), (b) guidelines for novice researchers on how to estimate, compare, report, and interpret ESEM, and (c) a step-by-step tutorial on how to run ESEM analyses in Mplus with the De Beer and Van Zy ESEM syntax generator. The results of this study highlight the value of ESEM, over and above that of traditional con\uFB01rmatory factor analytical approaches. The results also have practical implications for measuring mental health with the MHC-SF, illustrating that a bifactor ESEM Model \uFB01ts the data signi\uFB01cantly better than any other theoretical model.", 'call-number':"4.157", 'container-title':"Frontiers in Psychiatry", DOI:"10.3389/fpsyt.2021.795672", ISSN:"1664-0640", journalAbbreviation:"Front. Psychiatry", language:"en", page:"795672", source:"3", title:"Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling: Practical Guidelines and Tutorial With a Convenient Online Tool for Mplus", 'title-short':"Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling", volume:"12", author:[{family:"Zyl", given:"Llewellyn E.", 'non-dropping-particle':"van"}, {family:"Klooster", given:"Peter M.", 'non-dropping-particle':"ten"}], issued:{'date-parts':[["2022"]]}}, label:"page", 'suppress-author':true}], schema:"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}), These roles include those of child, pupil or student, leisurite, citizen, worker, spouse, homemaker, parent, and pensioner, positions with associated expectations that are occupied at some time by most people, and other less common roles such as those of criminal, reformer, and lover. A Life-Career Rainbow is presented as a means of helping conceptualize multidimensional careers, the temporal involvement in, and the emotional commitment to, each role. Self-actualization in various roles, role conflicts, and the determinants of role selection and of role performance are discussed. The use of the Rainbow in career education and in counseling is briefly considered.", 'container-title':"Journal of Vocational Behavior", DOI:"10/fvk7c8", journalAbbreviation:"Journal of Vocational 0.60,\u8868\u793A\u62DF\u5408\u7ED3\u679C\u826F\u597D\u3002\u9A8C\u8BC1\u6027\u56E0\u5B50\u5206\u6790\u4E2D\u6807\u51C6\u7EDD\u5BF9\u9002\u914D\u5EA6\u6307\u6807\u9009\u7528\u6E10\u8FDB\u6B8B\u5DEE\u5747\u65B9\u548C\u5E73\u65B9\u6839(RMSEA),\u5982\u5176<0.05,\u8868\u793A\u9002\u914D\u5EA6\u975E\u5E38\u597D;\u589E\u503C\u4E0E\u7B80\u7EA6\u9002\u914D\u5EA6\u6307\u6807\u5206\u522B\u9009\u7528\u6BD4\u8F83\u9002\u914D\u6307\u6570(CFI)\u548C\u7B80\u7EA6\u8C03\u6574\u540E\u7684\u975E\u89C4\u51C6\u9002\u914D\u5EA6\u6307\u6570(PNFI),\u5982\u5176\u6570\u503C> 0.90,\u8868\u793A\u9002\u914D\u5EA6\u975E\u5E38\u597D\u3002\u805A\u5408\u6548\u5EA6\u91C7\u7528\u5E73\u5747\u65B9\u5DEE\u62BD\u53D6\u91CF(AVE)\u8BC4\u4EF7,\u5F53AVE> (4)(+0000001): ZoteroWinWordIntegration: setCode ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"vZPlReKU","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(R. Curtis et al., 2016)","plainCitation":"(R. Curtis et al., 2016)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":"SOVY2tYh/mlwarkJW","uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9278983/items/58REE5KL"],"itemData":{"id":8335,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"Objectives:\nPerceived control may promote social activity in older adults because individuals with greater perceived control have greater confidence in their ability to achieve outcomes and are more likely to choose difficult activities, show persistence, and employ strategies to overcome challenges. Cross-sectional research has linked perceived control with social activity in life span and older adult samples but provides little insight into the direction of influence. We examined reciprocal associations between perceived control and social activity in order to establish temporal sequencing, which is one prerequisite for determining potential causation.\n\nMethod:\nParticipants were 14,126 midlife and older adults from the German Ageing Survey. Using cross-lagged autoregressive modeling with age as the time metric (40–87 years), we examined reciprocal 3-year lagged associations between perceived control and social activity, while controlling for concurrent associations.\n\nResults:\nPerceived control significantly predicted social activity 3 years later. Reciprocally, social activity significantly predicted perceived control 3 years later. The influence of perceived control on social activity was greater than the influence of social activity on perceived control.\n\nDiscussion:\nThe finding that perceived control significantly predicts future social activity has potential implications for developing interventions aimed at promoting social activity in midlife and older adults.","archive_location":"12 citation(s)","container-title":"The Journals of Gerontology Series B: Psychological Sciences and Social Sciences","DOI":"10.1093/geronb/gbw070","journalAbbreviation":"The Journals of Gerontology Series B: Psychological Sciences and Social Sciences","page":"807-815","source":"ResearchGate","title":"Perceived Control and Social Activity in Midlife and Older Age: A Reciprocal Association? Findings From the German Ageing Survey","title-short":"Perceived Control and Social Activity in Midlife and Older Age","volume":"73","author":[{"family":"Curtis","given":"Rachel"},{"family":"Huxhold","given":"O."},{"family":"Windsor","given":"Tim"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2016",6,17]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}
